questions.question_text: What does the UK offer to its permanent residents or citizens?

answers.text: A right to join in the election of a government
Free access to all national museums

questions.explanation: A right to join in the election of a governmentis the correct answer.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a fundamental principle of British life?

answers.text: Tolerance of those with different faiths and beliefs

questions.explanation: The fundamental principles of British life include: tolerance of those with different faiths and beliefs, the rule of law, democracy, individual liberty and participation in community life.

questions.question_text: What do you need to apply to become a permanent resident or citizen of the UK (choose TWO options)?

answers.text: To be able to speak and read English
A good understanding of life in the UK

questions.explanation: The UK offers to its residents or citizens: freedom of belief and religion, freedom of speech, freedom from unfair discrimination, a right to a fair trial and a right to join in the election of a government.

questions.question_text: What does the UK offer to its residents or citizens (choose FIVE answers)?

answers.text: A right to a fair trial
A right to join in the election of a government

questions.explanation: To apply to become a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you will needto speak and read English and have a good understanding of life in the UK.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a fundamental principle of life in the UK?

answers.text: Intolerance of those with different beliefs

questions.explanation: The fundamental principles of British life include: democracy, the rule of law,individual liberty, tolerance of those with different faiths and beliefs, and participation in community life.

questions.question_text: Which TWO of the following responsibilities will you have as a permanent resident or citizen of the UK?

answers.text: To respect and obey the law
To go to church on Sundays
To look after the area in which you live and the environment

questions.explanation: If you wish to be a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you should respect and obey the law, respect the rights of others, including their right to their own opinions, treat others with fairness, look after yourself and your family and look after the area in which you live and the environment.

questions.question_text: Participation in community life is a fundamental principle of British life.
questions.explanation: The fundamental principles of British life include:participation in community life.

questions.question_text: To look after yourself and your family is one of the responsibilities that you will have as a permanent resident or citizen of the UK.
questions.explanation: This statement isTRUE.

questions.question_text: In which of the following languages is the life in the UK test NOT available?
questions.explanation: The Life in the UK test is usually taken is English, although special arrangements can be made if you wish to take it in Welsh or Scottish Gaelic.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements is true?

answers.text: To apply to become a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you will need to have a university degree
To apply to become a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you will need to have a good understanding of life in the UK
To apply to become a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you will need to have British relatives
To apply to become a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you will need to have knowledge of the British laws

questions.explanation: To apply to become a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you will need to have a good understanding of life in the UK and be able to speak and read English.

questions.question_text: Which TWO of the following are fundamental principles of British life?

answers.text: Tolerance of those with different faiths and beliefs

questions.explanation: Tolerance of those with different faiths and beliefs and the rule of laware fundamental principles of British life.

questions.question_text: Which TWO of the following islands are known as ‘Crown dependencies’?
questions.explanation: There are also several islands which are closely linked with the UK but are not part of it: the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man. These have their own governments and are called ‘Crown dependencies’.

questions.question_text: What does the UK offer in return to its residents or citizens?

answers.text: A right to a fair trial

questions.explanation: A right to a fair trialis the correct answer.

questions.question_text: Which of the following territories does not belong to Great Britain?
questions.explanation: ‘Great Britain’ refers only to England, Scotland and Wales, not to Northern Ireland.

questions.question_text: Which of the following are British overseas territories?
questions.explanation: There are several British overseas territories in other parts of the world, such asSt Helena and the Falkland Islands. They are also linked to the UK but are not part of it.

questions.question_text: Where is the Parliament of the UK located?
questions.explanation: The UK is governed by the parliament sitting inWestminster.

questions.question_text: St Helena is a British overseas territory.

questions.question_text: The Isle of Man is a Crown dependency.

questions.question_text: British values and principles are based on history and traditions and are protected by law, customs and expectations.
questions.explanation: The Channel Islands and the Isle of Manare closely linked to the UK but are not part of it.

answers.text: I will give my loyalty to the United Kingdom
I will uphold its democratic values
I will observe its laws faithfully

questions.explanation: This statement istrue.

questions.question_text: Who was the first person to lead a Roman invasion in Britain in 55 BC?
questions.explanation: Julius Caesarled a Roman invasion of Britain in 55 BC.

questions.question_text: Which name is given to the tombs where people buried their dead during the Bronze Age?
questions.explanation: During the Bronze Age people lived in roundhouses and buried their dead in tombs calledround barrows.

questions.question_text: What did the ‘Bill of Rights‘ confirm in 1689?

answers.text: The rights of Parliament and the limits of the king‘s power
The supreme power of the king

questions.explanation: The Bill of Rights, 1689, confirmedthe rights of Parliament and the limits of the king’s power. Parliament took control of who could be monarch and declared that the king or queen must be a Protestant.

questions.question_text: Who designed the Clifton Suspension Bridge located over the Avon George?
questions.explanation: The Clifton Suspension Bridge was designed byIsambard Kingdom Bruneland is spanning the Avon Gorge.

questions.question_text: During the Middle Ages, England was an important trading nation and people came to England from abroad to trade and also to work. Where did the glass manufacturers come from?
Which American President worked closely with Margaret Thatcher?
questions.explanation: Margaret Thatcher worked closely with the United States President,Ronald Reagan, and was one of the first Western leaders to recognise and welcome the changes in the leadership of the Soviet Union which eventually led to the end of the Cold War.

questions.question_text: Who was the first Archbishop of Canterbury?
questions.explanation: St Augustinewas the first Archbishop of Canterbury.

questions.question_text: Who was the first wife of Henry VIII?
questions.explanation: Catherine of Aragonwas the first wife of Henry VIII.

questions.question_text: Which of the following flags is not represented in the union flag?
questions.explanation: The Welsh dragon does not appear on the Union Flagbecause, when the first Union Flag was created in 1606 from the flags of Scotland and England, the Principality of Wales was already united with England.

questions.question_text: When did ‘the Concorde’ aircraft fly for the first time?
questions.explanation: The Concorde first flewin 1969and began carrying passengers in 1976.

questions.question_text: By what other name is the Conservative Party also known as?
questions.explanation: The modern Conservative Party is still sometimes referred to asthe Tories.

questions.question_text: When did Adolf Hitler come to power in Germany?
questions.explanation: Adolf Hitler came to power in Germanyin 1933.

questions.question_text: What was inscribed in the first coins to be minted in Britain during the Iron Age?

answers.text: The names of Iron Age Kings

questions.explanation: They made the first coins to be minted in Britain, some inscribed withthe names of Iron Age kings.

questions.question_text: When did Emmeline Pankhurst set up the Women’s Franchise League, which fought to get the vote in local elections for married women?
questions.explanation: Emmeline Pankhurst was born in Manchester in 1858. She set up the women‘s Franchise Leaguein 1889, which fought to get the vote in local elections for married women. In 1903 she helped found the Women‘s Social and Political Union (WSPU).

questions.question_text: In which English county is the monument of Stonehenge located?
questions.explanation: The ancestors of these first farmers probably came from south-east Europe. These people built houses, tombs and monuments on the land. One of these monuments,Stonehenge, still stands in what is now the English county ofWiltshire.

questions.question_text: What is the best-known work from Robert Burns?
questions.explanation: Burns‘ best-known work is probably the songAuld Lang Syne, which is sung by people in the UK and other countries when they are celebrating the New Year (or Hogmanay as it is called in Scotland).

questions.question_text: Which of the following crosses does NOT form part of the Union Flag?

answers.text: The cross of St George, patron saint of England
The cross of St David, patron saint of Wales
The cross of St Patrick, patron saint of Ireland
The cross of St Andrew, patron saint of Scotland

questions.explanation: The cross of St David, patron saint of Walesdoes not form part of the Union Flag because, when the first Union Flag was created in 1606 from the flags of Scotland and England, the Principality of Wales was already untied with England.

questions.question_text: What British actor was best known for his roles in various Shakespeare plays?
questions.explanation: The Laurence Olivier Awards take place annually at different venues in London. There are a variety of categories, including best director, best actor and best actress. The awards are named after the British actorSir Laurence Olivier, late Lord Olivier, who was best known for his roles in various Shakespeare plays.

questions.question_text: What name is given to the period of rapid development of industry in Britain in the 18th and 19th centuries?
questions.explanation: The Industrial Revolutionwas the rapid development of industry in Britain in the 18th and 19th centuries.

questions.question_text: Who was responsible for the construction of the Great Western Railway?
questions.explanation: Isambard Kingdom Brunelwas responsible for constructing the Great Western Railway, which was the first major railway built in Britain.

questions.question_text: Which TWO of the following forts form part of Hadrian’s Wall?
questions.explanation: Parts of Hadrian‘s Wall include the forts ofHousesteads and Vindolanda.

questions.question_text: Why did Elizabeth I keep her cousin Mary prisoner for 20 years?

answers.text: She did not agree with her political views
She suspected Mary of wanting to take over the English throne
She was a spy of the Spanish Armada

questions.explanation: Elizabeth suspected Mary of wanting to take over the English throne, and kept her prisoner for 20 years.

questions.question_text: What was the name of the first cloned mammal?
questions.explanation: In 1996, two British scientists, Sir Ian Wilmot (1944-) and Keith Campbell (1954-2012), led a team which was the first to succeed in cloning a mammal,Dolly the sheep.

questions.question_text: How many British casualties were recorded during the First World War?
questions.explanation: During the First World War millions of people were killed or wounded, withmore than 2 million British casualties.

questions.question_text: Why did Henry VIII decide to divorce Catherine of Aragon?

answers.text: She was unpopular in the country
She was too old to give him another child
She was accused of taking lovers to the Palace

questions.explanation: WhenCatherine was too old to give him another child, Henry decided to divorce her, hoping that another wife would give him a son to be his heir.

questions.question_text: What characterised the Bronze Age?

answers.text: People were farmers who lived in large villages
People lived in roundhouses and buried their dead in tombs

questions.explanation: During the Bronze Agepeople lived in roundhouses and buried their dead in tombscalled round barrows.

questions.question_text: How many British citizens left the country between 1853 and 1913?
questions.explanation: Between 1853 and 1913, as many as13 million British citizensleft the country.

questions.question_text: Who was known as the Iron Duke?
questions.explanation: In 1815, the French Wars ended with the defeat of the Emperor Napoleon bythe Duke of Wellingtonat the Battle of Waterloo. Wellington was known as the Iron Duke and later became Prime Minister.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a British invention?
questions.explanation: The World Wide Web, the Turing machine and the hovercraft are British inventions.The mobile phoneis not.

questions.question_text: When did Argentina invade the Falklands Islands?
questions.explanation: In 1982, Argentina invaded the Falkland Islands, a British overseas territory in the South Atlantic.

questions.question_text: When did Alexander Fleming win the Nobel Prize in medicine for the discovery of penicillin?
questions.explanation: Fleming won the Nobel Prize in Medicinein 1945for the discovery of the penicillin.

questions.question_text: When did the Roman army leave Britain?
questions.explanation: The Roman army left Britainin AD 410to defend other parts of the Roman Empire and never returned.

questions.question_text: When was Emmeline Pankhurst born?
questions.explanation: Emmeline Pankhurst was born in Manchesterin 1858. She set up the women‘s Franchise League in 1889, which fought to get the vote in local elections for married women.

questions.question_text: How long did the First World War last for?
questions.explanation: The First World War lastedfour years (1914 – 1918).

questions.question_text: Who was Henry VII?

answers.text: The leader of the House of York
The leader of the House of Lancaster
The leader of the House of Buckingham
The leader of the House of Leeds

questions.explanation: Henry VII wasthe leader of the House of Lancaster.

questions.question_text: Which of the following areas did the British Empire NOT cover during the Victorian period?
questions.explanation: During the Victorian period, the British Empire grew to cover all of India, Australia and large parts of Africa.

questions.question_text: Which British scientist led the development of the atomic bomb?
questions.explanation: Scientists led byErnest Rutherford, working at Manchester and then Cambridge University, were the first to ‘split the atom‘ and took part in the Manhattan Project in the United States, which developed the atomic bomb.

questions.question_text: After the Black Death, the growing wealth in the towns led to the development of a strong middle class:
questions.explanation: True. After the Black Death, new social classes appeared, including owners of large areas of land (later called the gentry), and people left the countryside to live in the towns. In the towns, growing wealth led to the development of a strong middle class.

questions.question_text: What was the ability of the Harrier jump jet aircraft?
questions.explanation: The Harrier jump jet,an aircraft capable of taking off vertically, was also designed and developed in the UK.

questions.question_text: Which TWO of Henry VIII’s wives were accused of taking lovers and executed?
questions.explanation: Anne Boleyn and Catherine Howardwere accused of taking lovers and executed.

questions.question_text: Which two scientists led a team which was the first to succeed in cloning a mammal, Dolly the sheep?

answers.text: Sir Frank Whittle and Sir Christopher Cockrell
Sir Robert Edwards and Patrick Steptoe
Sir Ian Wilmot and Keith Campbell
Francis Creek and John Logie Baird

questions.explanation: In 1996, two British scientists,Sir Ian Wilmot(1944-)and Keith Campbell(1954-2012), led a team which was the first to succeed in cloning a mammal, Dolly the sheep.

questions.question_text: What British discovery was influential in the development of computer science and the modern-day computer?
questions.explanation: The Turing machineis a theoretical mathematical device invented by Alan Turing (1912-54), a British mathematician, in the 1930s. The theory was influential in the development of computer science and the modern-day computer.

questions.question_text: Which famous philosopher developed ideas about human nature during the 18th century and that have continued to influence philosophers over the years?
questions.explanation: During the 18th century,David Hume‘s ideas about human nature continue to influence philosophers.

questions.question_text: When did the ‘Concorde‘ aircraft carry passengers for the first time?
questions.explanation: The ‘Concorde‘ began carrying passengersin 1976.

questions.question_text: Which prehistoric village located in northern Europe has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age?
questions.explanation: Skara Braeon Orkney, off the north coast of Scotland, is the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe, and has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age.

questions.question_text: During the Middle Ages, a Parliament was developed in Scotland, which had three Houses called Estates. These were:

answers.text: The lords, the commons and the clergy
The lords, the commons and the farmers
The farmers, the blacksmiths and the clergy
The farmers, the blacksmiths and the teachers

questions.explanation: The Parliament developed in Scotland in the Middle Ages had three Houses, called Estates:the lords, the commons and the clergy.

questions.question_text: Which of the following scientific discoveries helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution?
questions.explanation: Scientific discoveries, such as James Watt‘s work onsteam power, helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution.

questions.question_text: Where in England was one of the Anglo-Saxon kings buried with treasure and armour?
questions.explanation: The burial place of one of the Anglo-Saxon kings was atSutton Hoo in modern Suffolk.

questions.question_text: Which of the following words comes from the Norman French (choose ONE option)?
questions.explanation: Some words in modern English – for example, ‘park‘ and‘beauty‘– are based on Norman French words.

questions.question_text: Catherine Parr, the sixth wife of Henry VIII, was Anne Boleyn’s cousin:
questions.explanation: False. Catherine Howard was a cousin of Anne Boleyn.

questions.question_text: What was the symbol of York during the Wars of the Roses?
questions.explanation: The symbol of York during the Wars of the Roses wasa white rose.

questions.question_text: During which movement the Parliament passed laws giving women the right to equal pay and made it illegal for employees to discriminate against women because of their gender:
questions.explanation: The Swinging Sixtieswas a time when the Parliament passed new laws giving women the right to equal pay and made it illegal for employers to discriminate against women because of their gender.

questions.question_text: Where can you find a statue of Boudicca, the queen of the Iceni and one of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans?
questions.explanation: There is a statue of Boudicca, the queen of the Iceni, onWestminster Bridgein London, near the Houses of Parliament.

questions.question_text: For how long was Britain a republic under the leadership of Oliver Cromwell?
questions.explanation: Britain was a republic under the leadership of Oliver Cromwellfor 11 years.

questions.question_text: Who became one of the most popular monarchs in English history, particularly after 1588, when the English defeated the Spanish Armada?
questions.explanation: Elizabeth Ibecame one of the most popular monarchs in English history, particularly after 1588, when the English defeated the Spanish Armada (a large fleet of ships), which had been sent by Spain to conquer England and restore Catholicism.

questions.question_text: When did the ‘Concorde‘ aircraft retire from service?
questions.explanation: The ‘Concorde‘ was retired from servicein 2003.

questions.question_text: When did the Allies defeat Germany marking the end of the Second World War?
questions.explanation: Following victory on the beaches of Normandy, the allied forces pressed on through France and eventually into Germany. The Allies comprehensively defeated Germanyin May 1945.

questions.question_text: During the Middle Ages, England was an important trading nation and people came to England from abroad to trade and also to work. Where did the weavers come from?
questions.explanation: During the Middle Ages, people came to England from abroad to trade and also to work. Many had special skills, such as weaversfrom France, engineers from Germany, glass manufacturers from Italy and canal builders from Holland.

questions.question_text: Throughout the 1990s, Britain played a leading role in coalition forces involved in the liberation of Kuwait, following the Iraqi invasion in 1990, and the conflict in the former Republic of Yugoslavia:
questions.explanation: True. Throughout the 1990s, Britain played a leading role in coalition forces involved in the liberation of Kuwait, following the Iraqi invasion in 1990, and the conflict in the former Republic of Yugoslavia.

questions.question_text: The ‘swinging sixties’ was a period of significant social change and it was known for its growth in:

answers.text: British fashion, cinema and popular music

questions.explanation: The decade of the 1960s was a period of significant social change. It was known as the ‘swinging sixties’. There was growth inBritish fashion, cinema and popular music.

questions.question_text: Which prehistoric village located in northern Europe has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age?
questions.explanation: Skara Braeon Orkney, off the north coast of Scotland, is the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe, and has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age.

questions.question_text: During the Middle Ages, a Parliament was developed in Scotland, which had three Houses called Estates. These were:

answers.text: The lords, the commons and the clergy
The lords, the commons and the farmers
The farmers, the blacksmiths and the clergy
The farmers, the blacksmiths and the teachers

questions.explanation: The Parliament developed in Scotland in the Middle Ages had three Houses, called Estates:the lords, the commons and the clergy.

questions.question_text: Which of the following scientific discoveries helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution?
questions.explanation: Scientific discoveries, such as James Watt’s work onsteam power, helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution.

questions.question_text: Who where the parents of Elizabeth I?

answers.text: Henry VII and Anne of Cleves
Henry VIII and Catherine of Aragon

questions.explanation: Henry VIII and Anne Boleynwere the parents of Elizabeth I.

questions.question_text: Which of the following areas did the British Empire NOT occupy during the Victorian period?
questions.explanation: During the Victorian period, the British Empire grew to cover all of India, Australia and large parts of Africa.

questions.question_text: Who were the first people to live in Britain in what we call the Stone Age?
questions.explanation: The first people to live in Britain werehunter-gatherers, in what we call the Stone Age.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements regarding the Black Death is NOT true?

answers.text: One third of the population of England died and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales
It was one of the worst disasters ever to strike Britain
It affected children and old people only
Following the Black Death, there were labour shortages

questions.explanation: In 1348, a disease, probably a form of plague, came to Britain. This was known as the Black Death. One third of the population of England died and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales. This was one of the worst disasters ever to strike Britain. Following the Black Death, the smaller population meant there was less need to grow cereal crops. There were labour shortages and peasants began to demand higher wages.

questions.question_text: Who was reigning in Britain when Wales became formally united with England by the Act for the Government of Wales?
questions.explanation: During the reign ofHenry VIII, Wales became formally united with England by the Act for the Government of Wales.

questions.question_text: The Elizabethan period is known for the richness of its poetry and drama, especially for the plays and poems of which playwright?
questions.explanation: The Elizabethan period is also remembered for the richness of its poetry and drama, especially the plays and poems ofWilliam Shakespeare.

questions.question_text: Which flag has a diagonal red cross on a white ground?

answers.text: The cross of St George, patron saint of England
The cross of St Patrick, patron saint of Ireland
The cross of St David, patron saint of Wales
The cross of St Andrew, patron saint of Scotland

questions.explanation: The cross of St Patrick, patron saint of Ireland, is a diagonal red cross on a white ground.

questions.question_text: What is the name of the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe and which origin traces back to the Stone Age?
questions.explanation: Skara Braeon Orkney, off the north coast of Scotland, is the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe, and has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age.

questions.question_text: After the Black Death, new social classes appeared in England, including owners of large areas of land known as:
questions.explanation: Following the Black Death, the smaller population meant there was less need to grow cereal crops. There were labour shortages and peasants began to demand higher wages. New social classes appeared, including owners of large areas of land (later calledthe gentry), and people left the countryside to live in the towns. In the towns, growing wealth led to the development of a strong middle class.

questions.question_text: Elizabeth I was the younger daughter of which King?
questions.explanation: Elizabeth I was the younger daughter ofHenry VIII.

questions.question_text: When did the First World War end?
questions.explanation: The First World War ended at 11.00 am on11th November 1918with victory for Britain and its allies.

questions.question_text: Which British scientist was awarded a Nobel Prize for discovering the structure of the DNA molecule?
questions.explanation: The structure of the DNA molecule was discovered in 1953 through work at British universities in London and Cambridge. This discovery contributed to many scientific advances, particularly in medicine and fighting crime.Francis Crick(1916-2004), one of those awarded the Nobel Prize for this discovery, was British.

questions.question_text: When did people learn how to make bronze?
questions.explanation: Around 4,000 years ago, people learned to make bronze. We call this period the Bronze Age.

questions.question_text: Who was Boudicca?

answers.text: One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans
One of the architects who built Hadrian’s Wall
One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Vikings

questions.explanation: One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romanswas Boudicca, the queen of the Iceni in what is now eastern England.

questions.question_text: What actions did Henry VII take after his victory in the Wars of the Roses?

answers.text: Reduced the power of the nobles
Broke away with the Church of Rome
Increased the power of the nobles

questions.explanation: After his victory in the Wars of the Roses, Henry VII wanted to make sure that England remained peaceful and that his position as king was secure. He deliberately strengthened the central administration of England andreduced the power of the nobles.

questions.question_text: Who became Prime Minister of the UK in May 2010?
questions.explanation: In May 2010, and for the first time in the UK since February 1974, no political party won an overall majority in the General Election. The Conservative and Liberal Democrat parties formed a coalition and the leader of the Conservative Party,David Cameron, became Prime Minister.

questions.question_text: How were Elizabeth I and ‘Mary, Queen of Scots’ related?
questions.explanation: Mary, Queen of Scots’ was Elizabeth I’s cousin.

questions.question_text: Choose the correct answer, the Middle Ages was:

answers.text: A period of peace in Britain
A period where liberal ideas were introduced in Britain
A period where new ideas about politics and philosophy were introduced in Britain

questions.explanation: The Middle Ages (or the medieval period) wasa time of almost constant war.

questions.question_text: What does the acronym NATO stand for?
questions.explanation: NATO stands forThe North Atlantic Treaty Organisation.

questions.question_text: What characterised the people from the Bronze Age?

answers.text: They were farmers who lived in large villages

questions.explanation: The people of the Bronze Age were accomplished metalworkerswho made many beautiful objects in bronze and gold, including tools, ornaments and weapons.

questions.question_text: What is the name of the event that refers to the 6 June 1944 when Allied Forces landed in Normandy aiming to attack Hitler’s forces in Western Europe during World War II?
questions.explanation: ‘D-Day’refers to the 6th of June 1944, when allied forces landed in Normandy aiming to attack Hitler’s forces in Western Europe during World War II.

questions.question_text: Which British Prime Minister led the Conservative government from 1979 to 1990?
questions.explanation: Margaret Thatcher, Britain’s first woman Prime Minister, led the Conservative government from 1979 to 1990.

questions.question_text: Which of the following civilisations is known for having built roads and public buildings, creating a structure of law and having introduced new plants and animals in Britain?
questions.explanation: The Romansremained in Britain for 400 years. They built roads and public buildings, created a structure of law, and introduced new plants and animals.

questions.question_text: What marked the beginning of what is called ‘constitutional monarchy’?

answers.text: The laws passed after the Glorious Revolution
A speech given by the King
The emergence of new ideas about politics, philosophy and science
The development of the Bessemer process

questions.explanation: The laws passed after the Glorious Revolutionare the beginning of what is called ‘constitutional monarchy’.

questions.question_text: When was the Turing machine discovered?
questions.explanation: A Turing machine is a theoretical mathematical device invented by Alan Turing (1912-54), a British mathematician,in the 1930s.

questions.question_text: During which period were the House of Lords and House of Commons established?
questions.explanation: In the Middle Ages, the numbers attending Parliament increased and two separate parts, known as Houses were established. These were the House of the Commons on the House of the Lords.

questions.question_text: How many years did Queen Victoria reign for?
questions.explanation: In 1837, Queen Victoria became queen of the UK at the age of 18. She reigned until 1901,almost 64 years.

questions.question_text: What is the name of Admiral Nelson’s ship?
questions.explanation: Admiral Nelson’s ship was known as theHMS Victory.

questions.question_text: What are the British scientists Sir Ian Wilmot and Keith Campbell famous for?

answers.text: The cloning of the first mammal, Dolly the sheep
The invention of the MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) scanner
The invention of the World Wide Web

questions.explanation: Sir Ian Wilmot and Keith Campbell led a team which was the first to succeed incloning a mammal, Dolly the sheep.

questions.question_text: Which of the following was one of the commanders in the defeat of the Spanish Armada and one of the founders of England’s naval tradition?
questions.explanation: Sir Francis Drakewas one of the commanders in the defeat of the Spanish Armada and one of the founders of England’s naval tradition.

questions.question_text: Who was the inventor of the World Wide Web?
questions.explanation: The inventor of the World Wide Web,Sir Tim Berners-Lee(1955-), is British. Information was successfully transferred via the web for the first time on 25 December 1990.

questions.question_text: When did the Wars of the Roses start?
questions.explanation: In 1455, a civil war was begun to decide who should be king of England. It was fought between the supporters of two families: the House of Lancaster and the House of York. This war was called the Wars of the Roses, because the symbol  of Lancaster was a red rose and the symbol of York was a white rose.

questions.question_text: When did the UK join the European Economic Community (EEC)?
questions.explanation: At first the UK did not wish to join the EEC but it eventually did soin 1973.

questions.question_text: Who defeated the French at the battle of Agincourt in 1415?
questions.explanation: One of the most famous battles of the Hundred Years War was the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, whereKing Henry V’s vastly outnumbered English army defeated the French.

questions.question_text: Which British Prime Minister nationalised major industries including coal and steel?
questions.explanation: Clement Attlee’s government undertook the nationalisation of major industries (like coal and steel), created the National Health Service and implemented many of Beveridge’s plans for a stronger welfare state. Attlee also introduced measures to improve the conditions of workers.

questions.question_text: Who was the first Archbishop of Canterbury?
questions.explanation: St Augustinebecame the first Archbishop of Canterbury.

questions.question_text: Which British explorer mapped the coast of Australia?
questions.explanation: Captain James Cookmapped the coast of Australia and a few colonies were established there.

questions.question_text: What were the main occupations of the people during the Iron Age?
questions.explanation: During the Iron Age most people werefarmers, craft workers or warriors.

questions.question_text: What was the name of Sir Francis Drake’s ship and which was one of the first to sail around the world?
questions.explanation: Sir Francis Drake, one of the commanders in the defeat of the Spanish Armada, was one of the founders of England’s naval tradition. His ship,the Golden Hind, was one of the first to sail right around (‘circumnavigate’) the world.

questions.question_text: Why did Henry VIII marry Anne of Cleves?
questions.explanation: Henry married Anne of Clevesfor political reasonsbut divorced her soon after.

questions.question_text: How many American colonies declared their independence in 1776, stating that people had a right to establish their own governments?
questions.explanation: In 1776,13 American coloniesdeclared their independence, stating that people had a right to establish their own governments.

questions.question_text: Where was Catherine of Aragon (the first wife of Henry VIII) from?
questions.explanation: Catherine of Aragon wasa Spanish princess.

questions.question_text: When did the post-war economic boom come to an end?
questions.explanation: In the late 1970s, the post-war economic boom came to an end.

questions.question_text: During her government, Margaret Thatcher made structural changes to the economy through the privatisation of nationalised industries and imposed legal controls on trade union powers:
questions.explanation: True. Margaret Thatcher made structural changes to the economy through the privatisation of nationalised industries and imposed legal controls on trade union powers.

questions.question_text: Who sat at the House of Commons during the Middle Ages?

answers.text: Knights and wealthy people from towns and cities
Everyone could sit at the House of Commons

questions.explanation: In the Middle Ages,Knights, who were usually smaller landowners,and wealthy people from towns and citieswere elected to sit in the House of Commons.

questions.question_text: Which of the following words come from the Anglo-Saxon language?
questions.explanation: The words‘Apple’ and ‘summer’are based on Anglo-Saxon words.

questions.question_text: How old was the Queen of Scotland, Mary Stuart, when she became queen?
questions.explanation: The queen of Scotland, Mary Stuart (often now called ‘Mary, Queen of Scots’) was a Catholic. She was onlya week oldwhen her father died and she became queen.

questions.question_text: Which British playwright had a great influence on the English language and invented many words that are still common today?
questions.explanation: William Shakespearehad a great influence on the English language and invented many words that are still common today.

questions.question_text: What proportion of the population died as a result of the Black Death in England?
questions.explanation: As a result of the Black Death,one third of the population of Englanddied and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales.

questions.question_text: Who wrote a famous series of poems in English about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage and known as ‘The Canterbury Tales’?
questions.explanation: In the years leading up to 1400,Geoffrey Chaucerwrote a series of poems in English about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage. The people decided to tell each other stories on the journey, and the poems describe the travellers and some of the stories they told.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a British invention of the 20th century?
questions.explanation: Radioactivityis not a British invention.

questions.question_text: Which British Prime Minister was famous for the speech ‘I have nothing to offer but blood, toil, tears and sweat’?
questions.explanation: During the Second World War,Winston Churchillmade many famous speeches including lines which you may still hear:  ‘I have nothing to offer but blood, toil, tears and sweat’. This was Churchill’s first speech to the House of Commons after he became Prime Minister, 1940.

questions.question_text: Which of the following countries did NOT belong to the Allies during World War II?
questions.explanation: Bulgariawas not part of the Allies during the Second World War.

questions.question_text: Which famous architect designed St Paul’s Cathedral after it was destroyed by a fire in 1666?
questions.explanation: In 1666, a great fire destroyed much of the city of London, including many churches and St Paul’s Cathedral. London was rebuilt with a new St Paul’s, which was designed by a famous architect,Sir Christopher Wren.

questions.question_text: Who proposed that enemy aircrafts could be detected by radio waves and is responsible for the development of the radar?
questions.explanation: Radar was developed by ScotsmanSir Robert Watson-Watt(1892-1973), who proposed that enemy aircraft could be detected by radio waves. The first successful radar test took place in 1935.

questions.question_text: Who sat at the House of Lords during the Middle Ages?

answers.text: Knights, who were usually smaller landowners
Wealthy people from towns and cities

questions.explanation: During the Middle Ages,great landowners and bishopssat in the House of Lords.

questions.question_text: Which of the following countries was NOT part of the Central Powers during the First World War?
questions.explanation: During the First World WarSerbiaformed part of the Allied powers.

questions.question_text: Who was the first English Prime Minister?
questions.explanation: The first man to be called this wasSir Robert Walpole, who was Prime Minister from 1721 to 1742.

questions.question_text: Who was Robert Burns?
questions.explanation: Known in Scotland as ‘The Bard’, Robert Burns wasa Scottish poet.

questions.question_text: Who established the Church of England?
questions.explanation: To divorce his first wife,Henry VIIIneeded the approval of the Pope. When the Pope refused, Henry established the Church of England. In this new church, the king, not the Pope, would have the power to appoint bishops and order how people should worship.

questions.question_text: What name is given to the period in the 18th century when new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed?
questions.explanation: During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed. This is often called‘the Enlightenment’.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of ‘Magna Carta’?
questions.explanation: The Magna Carta (which meansthe Great Charter). The Magna Carta established the idea that even the king was subject to the law. It protected the rights of the nobility and restricted the king’s power to collect taxes or to make and change laws.

questions.question_text: When did the Wars of the Roses end?
questions.explanation: The Wars of the Roses ended with the Battle of Bosworth Field in1485.

questions.question_text: The UK is not a full member of the European Union because it does not use the Euro currency:
questions.explanation: False. The UK is a full member of the European Union but does not use the Euro currency.

questions.question_text: Who was the British Minister after Margaret Thatcher?
questions.explanation: John Majorwas Prime Minister after Mrs Thatcher, and helped establish the Northern Ireland peace process.

questions.question_text: Who defeated Emperor Napoleon at the Battle of Waterloo in 1815?
questions.explanation: In 1815, the French Wars ended with the defeat of the Emperor Napoleon bythe Duke of Wellingtonat the Battle of Waterloo.

questions.question_text: What was the symbol of the House of Tudor?

answers.text: A red rose with a white rose inside it
A white rose with a red rose inside it

questions.explanation: The symbol of the House of Tudor wasa red rose with a white rose inside itas a sign that the Houses of York and Lancaster were now allies.

questions.question_text: What animal is represented in the Welsh flag?
questions.explanation: There is also an official Welsh flag, which showsa Welsh dragon. The Welsh dragon does not appear on the Union Flag because, when the first Union Flag was created in 1606 from the flags of Scotland and England, the Principality of Wales was already untied with England.

questions.question_text: Which famous economist developed ideas about economics during the 18th century and which are still referred to today?
questions.explanation: During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed. This is often called ‘the Enlightenment’. Many of the great thinkers of the Enlightenment were Scottish.Adam Smithdeveloped ideas about economics which are still referred to today.

questions.question_text: Who invented the cash-dispensing ATM (automatic teller machine) or ‘cashpoint’?
questions.explanation: In the 1960s,James Goodfellow(1937-) invented the cash-dispensing ATM (automatic teller machine) or ‘cashpoint’. The first of these was put into use by Barclays Bank in Enfield, north London in 1967.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of the term ‘Habeas corpus’?

answers.text: You must present the person in court

questions.explanation: Habeas corpus is Latin for‘you must present the person in court’. The Habeas Corpus Act guaranteed that no one could be held prisoner unlawfully. Every prisoner has a right to a court hearing.

questions.question_text: Which German princess got married with Henry VIII?
questions.explanation: Anne of Cleveswas a German princess who married Henry VIII for political reasons.

questions.question_text: What was the most spoken language during the Iron Age?
questions.explanation: The language spoken during the Iron Age was part ofthe Celtic languagefamily.

questions.question_text: Which of the following was one of the most famous battles of the Hundred Years War?
questions.explanation: One of the most famous battles of the Hundred Years War wasthe Battle of Agincourtin 1415, where King Henry V’s vastly outnumbered English army defeated the French. The English left France in the 1450s.

questions.question_text: During the Middle Ages, England was an important trading nation and people came to England from abroad to trade and also to work. Where did the engineers come from?
questions.explanation: During the Middle Ages, people came to England from abroad to trade and also to work. Many had special skills, such as weavers from France,engineers from Germany, glass manufacturers from Italy and canal builders from Holland.

questions.question_text: How many wives did Henry VIII have?
questions.explanation: Henry VIII hadsix wives.

questions.question_text: When did the English become the preferred language of the royal court and Parliament?
questions.explanation: By 1400, in England, official documents were being written in English, and English had become the preferred language of the royal court and Parliament.

questions.question_text: What was Boudicca, the queen of the Iceni in what is now eastern England, known for?
questions.explanation: One of the tribal leaders whofought against the Romanswas Boudicca, the queen of the Iceni in what is now eastern England.

questions.question_text: When was the hovercraft invented?
questions.explanation: Sir Christopher Cockerell (1910-99), a British inventor, invented the hovercraftin the 1950s.

questions.question_text: Who is the author of the famous play ‘Macbeth’?
questions.explanation: Macbeth is a famous play byWilliam Shakespeare.

questions.question_text: What animal was cloned by scientists Sir Ian Wilmot and Keith Campbell?
questions.explanation: In 1996, two British scientists, Sir Ian Wilmot (1944-) and Keith Campbell (1954-2012), led a team which was the first to succeed in cloning a mammal, Dolly thesheep.

questions.question_text: What did the Chartists campaign for?

answers.text: The right to vote for women over 30 years old
The right to vote for the working classes and other people without property
The right to vote for women and men over 30 years old
The right to vote for every citizen

questions.explanation: The Chartists, demandedthe vote for the working classes and other people without property.

questions.question_text: When did Emmeline Pankhurst die?
questions.explanation: Emmeline Pankhurst died in1928. Shortly before Emmeline’s death, women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, the same as men.

questions.question_text: What TWO houses were confronted during the Wars of the Roses?
questions.explanation: The Wars of the Roses were fought between the supporters of two families:the House of Lancaster and the House of York.

questions.question_text: Who was the first woman to become Prime Minister in the UK?
questions.explanation: Margaret Thatcher, Britain’s first woman Prime Minister, led the Conservative government from 1979 to 1990.

questions.question_text: How old was Queen Victoria when she became Queen in 1837?
questions.explanation: In 1837, Queen Victoria became queen of the UK at theage of 18.

questions.question_text: When did the First World War start?
questions.explanation: On 28 June1914, Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria was assassinated. This set off a chain of events leading to the First World War (1914-18).

questions.question_text: Which battle signified the end of the Wars of the Roses?
questions.explanation: The Wars of the Roses ended withthe Battle of Bosworth Fieldin 1485.

questions.question_text: Who became Prime Minister in the UK in May 1940?
questions.explanation: Winston Churchillwas the son of a politician and, before becoming a Conservative MP in 1900, was a soldier and journalist. In May 1940 he became Prime Minister.

questions.question_text: When did English settlers begin to colonise the eastern coast of America?
questions.explanation: In Elizabeth I’s time, English settlers first began to colonise the eastern coast of America.

questions.question_text: When did the Black Death come to England?
questions.explanation: In 1348, a disease, probably a form of plague, came to Britain. This was known as the Black Death.

questions.question_text: When did British combat troops leave Iraq?
questions.explanation: British combat troops left Iraqin 2009.

questions.question_text: The line ‘all the world’s a stage’ belongs to which of the following plays or poems written by William Shakespeare?
questions.explanation: All the world’s a stage’ are lines from William Shakespeare’s playAs You Like It.

questions.question_text: During the times of Elizabeth I, English settlers began to colonise:
questions.explanation: In Elizabeth I’s time, English settlers first began to colonisethe eastern coast of America.

questions.question_text: Which TWO families started a civil war to decide who should be king of England in 1455?
questions.explanation: In 1455, a civil war was begun to decide who should be king of England. It was fought between the supporters of two families:the House of Lancaster and the House of York.

questions.question_text: Who was in charge of the British fleet at the Battle of Trafalgar?
questions.explanation: Admiral Nelsonwas in charge of the British fleet at Trafalgar and was killed in the battle.

questions.question_text: Who was the leader of the English Republic?
questions.explanation: Oliver Cromwellwas the leader of the English republic.

questions.question_text: Where was Margaret Thatcher born?
questions.explanation: Margaret Thatcher was the daughter of a grocer from Grantham inLincolnshire.

questions.question_text: Who introduced the Statute of Rhuddlan by which Wales annexed to the Crown of England in 1284?
questions.explanation: In 1284King Edward I of Englandintroduced the Statute of Rhuddlan, which annexed Wales to the Crown of England.

questions.question_text: The decade of the 1960s was a period of significant social change, when there was growth in British fashion, cinema and popular music:
questions.explanation: True. The decade of the 1960s was a period of significant social change. It was known as the ‘swinging sixties’. There was growth in British fashion, cinema and popular music.

questions.question_text: When did Britain and France develop the world’s only supersonic commercial airliner known as ‘The Concorde’?
questions.explanation: The1960swas also a time of technological progress. Britain and France developed the world’s only supersonic commercial airliner, Concorde.

questions.question_text: Which flag has a diagonal white cross on a blue ground?

answers.text: The cross of St Andrew, patron saint of Scotland
The cross of St Patrick, patron saint of Ireland
The cross of St George, patron saint of England
The cross of St David, patron saint of Wales

questions.explanation: The cross of St Andrew, patron saint of Scotland, is a diagonal white cross on a blue ground.

questions.question_text: Which was the first major railway built in Britain?
questions.explanation: The Great Western Railway, which was the first major railway built in Britain.

questions.question_text: In the 15th century, Henry Tudor, the leader of the House of Lancaster, became:
questions.explanation: In 1485, Henry Tudor, the leader of the House of Lancaster, becameKing Henry VIIafter defeating King Richard III of the House of York at the Battle of Bosworth Field.

questions.question_text: Who defeated the Vikings?
questions.explanation: King Alfred the Greatdefeated the Vikings.

questions.question_text: During the Middle Ages, England was an important trading nation and people came to England from abroad to trade and also to work. Where did the canal builders come from?
questions.explanation: During this Middle Ages, England was an important trading nation and people came to England from abroad to trade and also to work.Canal builders came from Holland.

questions.question_text: The Elizabethan period in England was a time of growing patriotism: a feeling of pride in being English, English explorers sought new trade routes and tried to expand British trade into the Spanish colonies in the Americas:
questions.explanation: This statement isTRUE.

questions.question_text: How many crosses form the Union Flag?
questions.explanation: The Union Flag hasthree crosses.

questions.question_text: Who were the suffragettes?

answers.text: A group who demanded the vote for the working classes
A group who used civil disobedience to gain the vote for women
A group who campaigned for the vote of men over 21 years of age
A group who introduced new ideas about politics

questions.explanation: The suffragettes werea group who used civil disobedience to gain the vote for women.

questions.question_text: When did Henry VIII die?
questions.explanation: Henry VIII died on the 28th ofJanuary 1547.

questions.question_text: Which of the following lines from Shakespeare’s plays and poems is often still quoted?

answers.text: I have nothing to offer but blood, toil, tears and sweat

questions.explanation: The darling buds of May’ is a line from William Shakespeare’s play Sonnet 18 – Shall I Compare Thee To A Summer’s Day.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about Mary, Queen of the Scotland, is NOT true?

answers.text: She spent most of her childhood in France
She gave her throne to her Protestant son, James VI of Scotland.
She was kept her prisoner for 20 years

questions.explanation: The queen of Scotland,Mary Stuart(often now called ‘Mary, Queen of Scots’)was a Catholic.

questions.question_text: When did Ireland become unified with England, Wales and Scotland?
questions.explanation: In 1801, Ireland became unified with England, Scotland and Wales after the Act of Union of 1800. This created the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.

questions.question_text: What was the estimated population of the British Empire during the Victorian period?
questions.explanation: ﻿During the Victorian period, the British Empire became the largest empire the world has ever seen, with an estimated population ofmore than 400 million people.

questions.question_text: Which of the following countries was NOT part of the Allied Powers during the First World War?
questions.explanation: Bulgariawas part of the Central Powers.

questions.question_text: When did the First World War finish?
questions.explanation: The First World War endedat 11.00 am on 11th November 1918with victory for Britain and its allies.

questions.question_text: Florence Nightingale is known for her work on:

answers.text: The development of nursing in the UK
The development and manufacture of motor-sport technology

questions.explanation: Florence Nightingale is often regarded asthe founder of modern nursing.

questions.question_text: Which Act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire in 1833?
questions.explanation: In 1833the Emancipation Actabolished slavery throughout the British Empire.

questions.question_text: Who became King of England when Queen Anne died in 1714?
questions.explanation: When Queen Anne died in 1714, Parliament chose a German,George I, to be the next king, because he was Anne’s nearest Protestant relative.

questions.question_text: Who discovered the penicillin in 1928?
questions.explanation: Alexander Flemingwas researching influenza (the ‘flu’) in 1928 when he discovered penicillin.

questions.question_text: How many British casualties were recorded during the first day of the British attack of the Somme in July 1916 during the First World War?
questions.explanation: During the First World War, one battle, the British attack of the Somme in July 1916, resulted in about60,000 British casualtieson the first day alone.

questions.question_text: The Welsh dragon on the Welsh flag does not appear on the Union Flag because, when the first Union Flag was created in 1606 from the flags of Scotland and England, the Principality of Wales was already untied with England:
questions.explanation: This statement isTrue.

questions.question_text: Which two countries developed the ‘Concorde’ aircraft?
questions.explanation: Britain and Francedeveloped the world’s only supersonic commercial airliner, Concorde.

questions.question_text: Which Scottish physician and researcher co-discovered the insulin used to treat diabetes?
questions.explanation: John Macleod(1876-1935) was the co-discoverer of insulin, used to treat diabetes.

questions.question_text: Who was voted the greatest Briton of all time in 2002?
questions.explanation: Winston Churchillwas voted the greatest Briton of all time by the public in 2002.

questions.question_text: Which of the following social laws were liberalised during the 1960s?
questions.explanation: The 1960s was a time when social laws were liberalised, for example in relation to divorce and to abortion in England, Wales and Scotland.

questions.question_text: Who was the mother of Elizabeth I?
questions.explanation: Anne Boleynand Henry VIII had one daughter, Elizabeth I.

questions.question_text: When was the National Health System (NHS) established?
questions.explanation: In1948, Aneurin (Nye) Bevan, the Minister for Health, led the establishment of the National Health Service (NHS), which guaranteed a minimum standard of health care for all, free at the point of use.

questions.question_text: How many Russian and Polish Jews came to Britain to escape prosecution between 1870 and 1914?
questions.explanation: Between 1870 and 1914,around 120,000Russian and Polish Jews came to Britain to escape persecution.

questions.question_text: The line ‘a rose by any other name’ belongs to which of the following plays or poems written by William Shakespeare?
questions.explanation: A rose by any other name’ is a line from William Shakespeare’s playRomeo and Juliet.

questions.question_text: Which British scientist made important discoveries working with steam power?
questions.explanation: Scientific discoveries, such asJames Watt’s work on steam power, helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution.

questions.question_text: When was the first television broadcast made?
questions.explanation: In 1932Scotsman John Logie Baird made the first television broadcast between London and Glasgow.

questions.question_text: Who invented the hovercraft?

questions.question_text: According to the Citizenship Survey carried out in the UK in 2009, what percentage of the population identified themselves as Muslim?

questions.question_text: Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) are elected on the basis of:

answers.text: First past the post system (the candidate who gets the most votes)

questions.question_text: The North Atlantic Treaty Organisation is a group of European and North American countries that was created with which TWO purposes:

answers.text: Protect and promote human rights in those countries
Help each other if they come under attack
Maintain peace between all its members
Promote free trade amongst those countries

questions.explanation: NATO is a group of European and North American countries that have agreed to help each other if they come under attack. It also aims to maintain peace between all of its members.

questions.question_text: The small claims procedure is used in England and Wales for minor disputes for:

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements is true?

Proceedings in Parliament are not broadcast on television but published in official reports
Proceedings in Parliament are broadcast on the radio and not published in official reports
Proceedings in Parliament are broadcast on the radio only

questions.question_text: The public can listen to debates in the Palace of Westminster from public galleries in the House of Commons but not in the House of Lords:
questions.explanation: False. The public can listen to debates in the Palace of Westminster from public galleries in both the House of Commons and the House of Lords.

questions.question_text: Which of the following organisations has no power to make laws but draws up conventions and charters, including the European Convention on Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms?
questions.explanation: The Council of Europeis responsible for the protection and promotion of human rights in those countries. It has no power to make laws but draws up conventions and charters, the most well-known of which is the European Convention on Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms, usually called the European Convention on Human Rights.

questions.question_text: Which Court deals with the most serious criminal cases, such as murder, in Scotland?

questions.explanation: The leader of the opposition leads his or her party in pointing out what they see as the government’sfailures and weaknesses.

questions.question_text: What is the minimum age requirement to drive a mopped in the UK?

questions.question_text: What is donated blood used for?

questions.question_text: The House of Commons is normally more independent of the government than the House of Lords:

questions.question_text: How can MPs be contacted (choose TWO options)?

answers.text: By going to your local council and asking for an appointment

questions.explanation: MPs can be contactedby letter or telephone at their constituency office, or at their office in the House of Commons. In addition, many MPs, SMs and MSPs hold regular local ‘surgeries’, where constituents can go in person to talk about issues that are of concern to them.

questions.question_text: Does Britain have a written constitution?
questions.explanation: The British constitution is not written downin any single document, and therefore it is described as ‘unwritten’. This is mainly because the UK, unlike America or France, has never had a revolution which led permanently to a totally new system of government.

questions.question_text: When were the United Nations set up?

answers.text: Before the War of the Roses

questions.question_text: Where can you find copies of the ‘Hansard’?

answers.text: In large libraries and at www.parliament.uk

questions.explanation: Proceedings in Parliament are broadcast on television and published in official reports called Hansard. Written reports can be foundin large libraries and at www.parliament.uk.

questions.question_text: Which court normally deals with cases of children aged 10 to 17 in England, Wales and Northern Ireland?
questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, if an accused person is aged 10 to 17, the case is normally heard in aYouth Courtin front of up to three specially trained magistrates or a District Judge. The most serious cases will go the Crown Court.

questions.question_text: How many senior MPs are appointed by the Prime Minister?

questions.question_text: What name is given to the elected members of the European Parliament?
questions.explanation: Elections for the European Parliament are held every five years. Elected members are called members of the European Parliament (MEPs).

questions.question_text: Which court deals with cases involving personal injury, family matters, breaches of contract and divorce in England and Wales?

These include people trying to get back money that is owed to them, cases involving personal injury, family matters, breaches of contract, and divorce. In Scotland, most of these matters are dealt with in the Sheriff Court.

questions.explanation: In Scotland the elected members, called MSPs, meet in the Scottish Parliament building atHolyroodin Edinburgh.

Junior opposition MPs appointed by the leader of the opposition

A driving licence and a valid motor insurance only

questions.question_text: What does the term ‘coalition’ refer to?

questions.question_text: In which TWO cases may a person who has been summoned to do jury service be exempted from doing it:

If they have to go to work

questions.question_text: What is the role of the shadow cabinet?

questions.question_text: If you are self-employed:

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT classified as a criminal offence in the UK?

answers.text: Unfair dismissal or discrimination in the workplace

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT considered to be a main part of the British government?

questions.question_text: Which court usually deals with the MOST serious civil cases in Scotland?

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements is TRUE?

answers.text: Forcing another person to marry is a civil offence
Forcing another person to marry is a criminal offence
Forcing another person to marry is not punished in the UK
Forcing another person to marry is common in the UK

questions.question_text: Where do UK residents need to register their car or motorcycle?

answers.text: At the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA)

questions.question_text: Which court deals with serious criminal offences in Wales?

questions.question_text: When were Protection Orders to protect a person from being forced into a marriage, or to protect a person in a forced marriage introduced for Scotland?
questions.explanation: Forced Marriage Protection Orders were introduced in 2008 for England, Wales and Northern Ireland under the Forced Marriage (Civil Protection) Act 2007. Court orders can be obtained to protect a person from being forced into a marriage, or to protect a person in a forced marriage. Similar Protection Orders were introduced in Scotland in November2011.

questions.question_text: Since when have hereditary peers lost the automatic right to attend the House of Lords?
questions.explanation: ﻿Since 1999, hereditary peers have lost the automatic right to attend the House of Lords.

questions.question_text: How many countries are members of the United Nations?

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements is true?

answers.text: The police force is a public service that helps and protects everyone
The police force is a private service that helps and protects everyone

questions.question_text: What is the system by which the income tax is automatically taken from the employee’s income by their employer and paid directly to HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC)?
questions.explanation: For most people, the right amount of income tax is automatically taken from their income from employment by their employer and paid directly to HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC), the government department that collects taxes. This system is called“Pay As You Earn” (PAYE).

questions.question_text: What Treaty established the European Economic Union in 1957?
questions.explanation: The European Union (EU), originally called the European Economic Community (EEC), was set up by six western European countries (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands) who signedthe Treaty of Romeon 25 March 1957.

questions.question_text: When did hereditary peers lose the automatic right to attend the House of Lords?
questions.explanation: Since1999, hereditary peers have lost the automatic right to attend the House of Lords. They now elect a few of their number to represent them in the House of Lords.

questions.question_text: Members of the public are not allowed in Youth Courts, and the name or photographs of the accused young person cannot be published in newspapers or used by the media:

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of the term ‘first past the post’?

questions.question_text: Which court deals with the MOST serious criminal cases in Scotland, such as murder?
questions.explanation: In Scotland, serious cases are heard in a Sheriff Court with either a sheriff or a sheriff with a jury. The most serious cases in Scotland, such as murder, are heard at aHigh Courtwith a judge and jury.
