questions.question_text: If you are arrested and taken to a police station, a police officer should:

answers.text: Make a copy of your ID and retain you until your lawyer arrives
Tell you the reason for your arrest and that you will be able to seek legal advice
Offer you a cup of tea
Explain the law to you and wait for your family to arrive

questions.explanation: If you are arrested and taken to a police station, a police officer willtell you the reason for your arrest and you will be able to seek legal advice.

questions.question_text: The UK is one of the five permanent members of the Security Council:
questions.explanation: This statement istrue.

questions.question_text: Which of the following four changes did the Chartists NOT campaign for?

answers.text: For any man to be able to stand as MP

questions.explanation: The Chartists campaigned for every man to have the vote,elections every year, for all regions to be equal in the electoral system, secret ballots, for any man to be able to stand as an MP and for MPs to be paid.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a criminal offence?

answers.text: Selling tobacco to someone under the age of 18

questions.explanation: It is illegal and a criminal offenceto sell tobacco products(for example, cigarettes, cigars, roll-up tobacco)to anyone under the age of 18.

questions.question_text: Which court deals with serious criminal offences in Northern Ireland?
questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, serious criminal offences are tried in front of a judge and a jury in aCrown Court.

questions.question_text: Which political party does the Speaker represent?

answers.text: The Speaker does not represent any political party

questions.explanation: The Speaker is neutral and does not represent a political party, even though he or she is an MP, represents a constituency and deals with the constituents’ problems like any other MP.

questions.question_text: When was the Scottish Parliament formed?
questions.explanation: The Scottish Parliament was formed in1999.

questions.question_text: Who is the heir to the throne of the UK?
questions.explanation: The King’s eldest son,Prince William (the Prince of Wales), is the heir to the throne.

questions.question_text: Membership to the Commonwealth is compulsory for its members:
questions.explanation: False. Membership to the Commonwealth isvoluntary.

questions.question_text: How many verdicts are possible in trials in Scotland?
questions.explanation: The jury has to listen to the evidence presented at the trial and then decide a verdict of‘guilty’or‘not guilty’based of what they have heard. In Scotland, a third verdict of‘not proven’is also possible.

questions.question_text: Which of the following charities works with sick animals?
questions.explanation: The PDSAis the People’s Dispensary for Sick Animals.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the responsibility of the Home Secretary?
questions.explanation: The Home Secretary is responsible forcrime, policing and immigration.

questions.question_text: What is the minimum age required for a citizen to stand for public office?
questions.explanation: Most citizens of the UK, the Irish republic or the Commonwealth aged18or over can stand for public office.

questions.question_text: Who makes sure that the opposition has a guaranteed amount of time to debate issues which it chooses during political debates?
questions.explanation: The Speakerkeeps order during political debates to make sure the rules are followed. This includes making sure the opposition has a guaranteed amount of time to debate issues which it chooses.

questions.question_text: Citizens of Liechtenstein can drive in the UK for as long as their driving license is valid:
questions.explanation: True. If your driving licence if from a country in the European Union (EU), Iceland, Liechtenstein or Norway, you can drive in the UK for as long as your licence is valid.

questions.question_text: What is the money raised from the Income Tax used for (choose THREE options)?
questions.explanation: Money raised from income tax pays for government services such asroads, education, police and the armed forces.

questions.question_text: When were the Forced Marriage Protection Orders introduced for England, Wales and Northern Ireland, which aimed at protecting a person from being forced into a marriage, or to protect a person in a forced marriage?
questions.explanation: Forced Marriage Protection Orders were introduced in2008for England, Wales and Northern Ireland under the Forced Marriage (Civil Protection) Act 2007.

questions.question_text: In the UK, if the jury finds a defendant guilty, the judge decides the penalty:
questions.explanation: This statement istrue.

questions.question_text: Which of the following countries is a member of the Commonwealth?
questions.explanation: Bangladeshis a member of the Commonwealth.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a principle included in the European Convention of Human Rights?

answers.text: Prohibition of slavery and forced labour

questions.explanation: Prohibition of  immoral thoughtsis not one of the principles included in the European Convention of Human Rights.

questions.question_text: A system of government where the whole adult population gets a say is known as:
questions.explanation: Democracyis a system of government where the whole adult population gets a say. This might be by direct voting or by choosing representatives to make decisions on their behalf.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements is correct?

answers.text: Arranged marriages refer to marriages where both parties agree to the marriage
Arranged marriages refer to marriages where one or both parties do not give their consent to enter into the partnership

questions.explanation: Arranged marriages refer to marriages where both parties agree to the marriage.

questions.question_text: The devolved governments in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland have the power to legislate on any issues that affect them:
questions.explanation: False. Devolved governments in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland have the power to legislateon certain issues.

questions.question_text: What name is given to the members of the House of Commons?
questions.explanation: All of the electedMPsform the House of Commons.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a role of the King:

answers.text: To inaugurate important business in the UK
To receive foreign ambassadors and high commissioners
To entertain visiting heads of state

questions.explanation: The King receives foreign ambassadors and high commissioners, entertains visiting heads of state, and makes state visits overseas in support of diplomatic and relationships with other counties.

questions.question_text: The Speaker is a neutral MP and does not represent a political party:
questions.explanation: True. The Speaker is neutral and does not represent a political party, even though he or she is an MP, represents a constituency and deals with the constituents’ problems like any other MP.

questions.question_text: How can a person facing domestic violence find a safe place to stay (choose TWO options)?

answers.text: Going to a hotel away from their home
Contacting the National Domestic Violence Freephone Helpline

questions.explanation: If you are facing domestic violence you can get help from the 24-hour National Domestic Violence Freephone Helpline on 0808 2000 247 at any time, or the police can help you find a safe place to stay.

questions.question_text: Who has control over policy and laws governing defence, foreign affairs, immigration, taxation and social security in Northern Ireland?
questions.explanation: Policy and laws governing defence, foreign affairs, immigration, taxation and social security all remain undercentral UK governmentcontrol. However, many other public services, such as education, are controlled by the devolved administrations.

questions.question_text: The devolved governments in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland cannot control policies and laws governing taxation and social security:
questions.explanation: True. Policy and laws governing defence, foreign affairs, immigration, taxation and social security all remain under central UK government control. However, many other public services, such as education, are controlled by the devolved administrations.

questions.question_text: In the UK, brutality and violence in the home is not a crime:
questions.explanation: False. In the UK, brutality and violence in the homeis a serious crime.

questions.question_text: UK laws ensure that people are not treated unfairly in any area of life or work because of their age, disability, sex, pregnancy and maternity, race, religion or belief, sexuality or marital status:
questions.explanation: This statement istrue.

questions.question_text: Since 1997, some powers have been devolved from the central government to give people in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland more control over matters that directly affect them:
questions.explanation: This statement istrue.

questions.question_text: How can you visit the Senedd?
questions.explanation: To make a booking to visit the Senedd, you have tocontact the Senedd Booking Service.

questions.question_text: In which of the following matters the Scottish Parliament CANNOT legislate?
questions.explanation: The matters on which the Scottish Parliament can legislate include: civil and criminal law, health, education, planning and additional tax-raising powers.

questions.question_text: Does Britain have a constitutional monarchy?
questions.explanation: True. The UK has a constitutional monarchy.

questions.question_text: The devolved administrations of Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland each have their own civil service:
questions.explanation: True. The devolved administrations each have their own civil service.

questions.question_text: Carrying a weapon is a criminal offence, unless it is for self-defence:
questions.explanation: False. It is a criminal offence to carry a weapon of any kind, even if it is for self-defence. This includes a gun, a knife or anything that is made or adapted to cause injury.

questions.question_text: Prohibition of thought, conscience and religion is one of the principles included in the European Convention of Human Rights:
questions.explanation: False. Freedom of thought, conscience and religion is one of the principles included in the European Convention of Human Rights

questions.question_text: Will a non-UK national living in the UK and looking for work, starting work or setting up as self-employed need a National Insurance number?
questions.explanation: True. A non-UK national living in the UK and looking for work, starting work or setting up as self-employed will need a National Insurance number. However, you can start work without one.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a responsibility of the MPs?

answers.text: Scrutinise and comment on what the government is doing

questions.explanation: MPs have a number of different responsibilities. They represent everyone in their constituency, help to create new laws, scrutinize and comment on what the government is doing and debate important national issues.

questions.question_text: The clock tower is named ‘Elizabeth Tower’ in honour of:

answers.text: Queen Elizabeth II’s Diamond Jubilee in 2012
Queen Elizabeth I’s Diamond Jubilee in 2012
Queen Elizabeth II’s Golden Jubilee in 2002
Queen Elizabeth I’s Golden Jubilee in 2002

questions.explanation: The clock tower is named ‘Elizabeth Tower’ in honour ofQueen Elizabeth II’s Diamond Jubilee in 2012.

questions.question_text: The right to a fair trial is not included amongst the principles of the European Convention of Human Rights:
questions.explanation: False. The right to a fair trial is one of the principles of the European Convention of Human Rights.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT classified as a criminal offence in the UK?

answers.text: Selling alcohol to anyone under the age of 18
Unfair dismissal or discrimination in the workplace

questions.explanation: Cases of unfair dismissal or discrimination in the workplace are considered civil offences.

questions.question_text: The right to life and the right to liberty and security are some of the principles included in the European Convention of Human Rights:
questions.explanation: This istrue.

questions.question_text: When are local elections for councillors held in most local authorities?
questions.explanation: For most local authorities, local elections for councillors are heldin May every year.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT protected by the laws of discrimination?
questions.explanation: UK laws ensure that people are not treated unfairly in any area of life or work because of their age, disability, sex, pregnancy and maternity, race, religion or belief, sexuality or marital status.

questions.question_text: Which of the following countries is NOT a member of the Commonwealth?
questions.explanation: Greeceis not a member of the Commonwealth.

questions.question_text: In England, Wales and Scotland, most minor criminal cases are dealt with in a Magistrates’ Court:
questions.explanation: False. In England, Wales andNorthern Ireland, most minor criminal cases are dealt with in a Magistrates’ Court. In Scotland, minor criminal offences go to a Justice of the Peace Court.

questions.question_text: When did the UK sign the European Convention of Human Rights?
questions.explanation: The UK was one of the first countries to sign the Convention in1950.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a devolved administration?
questions.explanation: There are three devolved administrations in the UK, this include: the Senedd, the Scottish Parliament and the Northern Ireland Assembly.

questions.question_text: What was the name of the European Union when it was first established?
questions.explanation: The European Union (EU), originally calledthe European Economic Community (EEC), was set up by six western European countries (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands) who signed the Treaty of Rome on 25 March 1957.

questions.question_text: Which Act incorporated the European Convention of Human Rights into UK law?
questions.explanation: The Human Rights Act 1998incorporated the European Convention of Human Rights into UK law.

questions.question_text: Arranged marriages are not acceptable in the UK:
questions.explanation: False. Arranged marriages, where both parties agree to the marriage, are acceptable in the UK.

questions.question_text: Who represents the UK to the rest of the world?
questions.explanation: The Kingrepresents the UK to the rest of the world.

questions.question_text: Who is responsible for managing relationships with foreign countries?
questions.explanation: The Foreign Secretaryis responsible for managing relationships with foreign countries.

questions.question_text: If a husband forces his wife to have sex, he can be charged with rape:
questions.explanation: True. Any man who forces a woman to have sex, including a woman’s husband, can be charged with rape.

questions.question_text: Who were the first people to arrive in Britain in what we call the Stone Age?
questions.explanation: The first people to live in Britain werehunter-gatherers, in what we call the Stone Age.

questions.question_text: When did Britain become permanently separated from the continent by the Channel?
questions.explanation: Britain only became permanently separated from the continent by the Channel about10,000 years ago.

questions.question_text: The Commonwealth has no power over its members and it cannot suspend their membership:
questions.explanation: The Commonwealth has no power over its members, although it can suspend membership.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements regarding the Black Death is NOT true?

answers.text: One third of the population of England died and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales
It was one of the worst disasters ever to strike Britain
It affected children and old people only
Following the Black Death, there were labour shortages

questions.explanation: In 1348, a disease, probably a form of plague, came to Britain. This was known as the Black Death. One third of the population of England died and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales. This was one of the worst disasters ever to strike Britain. Following the Black Death, the smaller population meant there was less need to grow cereal crops. There were labour shortages and peasants began to demand higher wages.

questions.question_text: Who was reigning in England when Wales became formally united with England by the Act for the Government of Wales?
questions.explanation: During the reign ofHenry VIII, Wales became formally united with England by the Act for the Government of Wales.

questions.question_text: The Elizabethan period is known for the richness of its poetry and drama, especially for the plays and poems of which playwright?
questions.explanation: The Elizabethan period is remembered for the richness of its poetry and drama, especially the plays and poems ofWilliam Shakespeare.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a fundamental principle of British life?

answers.text: Tolerance of those with different faiths and beliefs

questions.explanation: The fundamental principles of British life include: tolerance of those with different faiths and beliefs, the rule of law, democracy, individual liberty and participation in community life.

questions.question_text: Which TWO of the following are environmental charities?
questions.explanation: The National Trust and Friends of the Earth are environmental charities.

questions.question_text: Which flag has a diagonal red cross on a white ground?

answers.text: The cross of St George, patron saint of England
The cross of St Patrick, patron saint of Ireland
The cross of St David, patron saint of Wales
The cross of St Andrew, patron saint of Scotland

questions.explanation: The cross of St Patrick, patron saint of Ireland, is a diagonal red cross on a white ground.

questions.question_text: Where is the city of Swansea located?
questions.explanation: Swansea is located inWales.

questions.question_text: When is Christmas Eve celebrated?
questions.explanation: Christmas Eve is celebrated on the 24th of December.

questions.question_text: Which British sportsman won five consecutive gold medals at the Olympic Games in the rowing category?
questions.explanation: Sir Steve Redgravewon gold medals in rowing in five consecutive Olympic Games and is one of Britain’s greatest Olympians.

questions.question_text: What is the name of the centrepiece to the Remembrance Day service located in Whitehall, London?
questions.explanation: The Cenotaph in Whitehall is the site of the annual Remembrance Day service attended by the King, politicians and foreign ambassadors.

questions.question_text: Who was the inventor of the World Wide Web?
questions.explanation: The inventor of the World Wide Web, Sir Tim Berners-Lee (1955-), is British. Information was successfully transferred via the web for the first time on 25 December 1990.

questions.question_text: What does the UK offer to its residents or citizens (choose FIVE answers)?

answers.text: A right to a fair trial
A right to join in the election of a government

questions.explanation: The UK offers to its residents or citizens: freedom of belief and religion, freedom of speech, freedom from unfair discrimination, a right to a fair trial and a right to join in the election of a government.

questions.question_text: When did the Wars of the Roses start?
questions.explanation: In 1455, a civil war was begun to decide who should be king of England. It was fought between the supporters of two families: the House of Lancaster and the House of York. This war was called the Wars of the Roses, because the symbol of Lancaster was a red rose and the symbol of York was a white rose.

questions.question_text: How many members does the Scottish Parliament have?
questions.explanation: There are 129 members of the Scottish Parliament (MSPs), elected by a form of proportional representation.

questions.question_text: What does the term ‘coalition’ refer to?

answers.text: If no political party wins a majority, a new election is held to vote for one of the top two parties only
The candidate who gets the most votes is elected
If no political party wins a majority, two parties may join and govern together
If an MP dies or resigns, there will be a fresh election

questions.explanation: The government is usually formed by the party that wins the majority of constituencies. If no party wins a majority, two parties may join together to form a coalition.

questions.question_text: The public can listen to debates in the Palace of Westminster from public galleries in both the House of Commons and the House of Lords.
questions.explanation: This statement istrue.

questions.question_text: Pool and darts are traditional pub games.
questions.explanation: True.

questions.question_text: When did the UK formally leave the European Union?
questions.explanation: The UK formally left the European Union on31 January 2020.

questions.question_text: What is the minimum age requirement in the UK to drink wine or beer with a meal provided you are with someone over 18?
questions.explanation: When they are 16, people can drink wine or beer with a meal in a hotel or restaurant (including eating areas in pubs) as long as they are with someone over 18.

questions.question_text: Who is the spiritual leader of the Church of England?
questions.explanation: The spiritual leader of  the Church of England isthe Archbishop of Canterbury.

questions.question_text: Civil servants cannot stand for public office:
questions.explanation: Most citizens of the UK, Ireland or the Commonwealth aged 18 or over can stand for public office. There are some exceptions, including: members of the armed forces, civil servants, people found guilty of certain criminal offences.

questions.question_text: Which Scottish city is known as the home of golf?
questions.explanation: St. Andrews in Scotland is known as the home of golf.

questions.question_text: Which court deals with the most serious cases of children aged 10 to 17 in England, Wales and Northern Ireland?
questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, if an accused person is aged 10 to 17, the case is normally heard in a Youth Court in front of up to three specially trained magistrates or a District Judge. The most serious cases will gothe Crown Court.

questions.question_text: What is the name of the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe and which origin traces back to the Stone Age?
questions.explanation: Skara Braeon Orkney, off the north coast of Scotland, is the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe, and has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age.

questions.question_text: When was the National Trust founded?
questions.explanation: The National Trust was founded in1895by three volunteers.

questions.question_text: After the Black Death, new social classes appeared in England, including owners of large areas of land known as:
questions.explanation: Following the Black Death, the smaller population meant there was less need to grow cereal crops. There were labour shortages and peasants began to demand higher wages. New social classes appeared, including owners of large areas of land (later called thegentry), and people left the countryside to live in the towns. In the towns, growing wealth led to the development of a strong middle class.

questions.question_text: Elizabeth I was the younger daughter of which King?
questions.explanation: Elizabeth I was the younger daughter ofHenry VIII.

questions.question_text: Which of the following operas was written by Gilbert and Sullivan?
questions.explanation: In the 19th century, Gilbert and Sullivan wrote comic operas, often making fun of popular culture and politics. These operas include HMS Pinafore, The Pirates of Penzance andThe Mikado.

questions.question_text: Where is Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park located?
questions.explanation: Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park is located in thewest of Scotland.

questions.question_text: Who is married to the King of the United Kingdom?
questions.explanation: The King of the United Kingdom is married to Camila, the Queen Consort.

questions.question_text: By what TWO other names is the Church of England known?
questions.explanation: The official Church of the state is the Church of England (called theAnglican Churchin other countries and theEpiscopal Churchin Scotland and the United States).

questions.question_text: Who was the first British Prime Minister?
questions.explanation: The first man to British Prime Minister wasSir Robert Walpole, who was Prime Minister from 1721 to 1742.

questions.question_text: What day does Lent start?
questions.explanation: Lent begins on Ash Wednesday.

questions.question_text: How old do you need to be to apply for a free TV licence?
questions.explanation: Peopleover 75can apply for a free TV licence and blind people can get a 50% discount.

questions.question_text: What time do pubs usually open on Sundays in the UK?
questions.explanation: Pubs are usually open during the day from 11.00 am (12 noon on Sundays).

questions.question_text: What is the official home of the Prime Minister?
questions.explanation: The official home of the Prime Minister is 10 Downing Street, in central London, near the Houses of Parliament. He or she also has a country house outside London called Chequers.

questions.question_text: When did the Conservative government called a referendum on the UK’s membership of the European Union?
questions.explanation: The Conservative government called a referendum on the UK’s membership of the European Union on the 23rd June 2016.

questions.question_text: Which British sportswoman won two gold medals for running in the 2004 Olympic Games?
questions.explanation: Dame Kelly Holmes won two gold medals for running in the 2004 Olympic Games. She has held a number of British and European records.

questions.question_text: What percentage of the total British population is located in England alone?
questions.explanation: The population is very unequally distributed over the four parts of the UK. England more or less consistently makes up 84% of the total population, Wales around 5%, Scotland just over 8%, and Northern Ireland less than 3%.

questions.question_text: What was the population of the UK in 2010?
questions.explanation: The population of the UK in 2010 was just over 62 million people.

questions.question_text: Which court deals with cases involving personal injury, family matters, breaches of contract and divorce in England and Wales?
questions.explanation: County Courts deal with a wide range of civil disputes. These include people trying to get back money that is owed to them, cases involving personal injury, family matters, breaches of contract, and divorce. In Scotland, most of these matters are dealt with in the Sheriff Court.

questions.question_text: What is the name of the building where the Scottish Parliament meet?
questions.explanation: In Scotland the elected members, called MSPs, meet in the Scottish Parliament building atHolyroodin Edinburgh.

questions.question_text: Which flower is associated with England?
questions.explanation: The rose is the flower associated with England.

questions.question_text: Who was Robert Burns?
questions.explanation: Known in Scotland as ‘The Bard’, Robert Burns was aScottish poet.

questions.question_text: In which period did British Film studios flourish?
questions.explanation: British film studios flourished in the 1930s.

questions.question_text: What is the capital city of Northern Ireland?
questions.explanation: The capital city of Northern Ireland isBelfast.

questions.question_text: What name is given to the day when people play jokes on each other until midday?
questions.explanation: April Fool’s Day, 1 April, is a day when people play jokes on each other until midday. The television and newspapers often have stories that are April Fool jokes.

questions.question_text: Who is the fastest person to have sailed around the world single-handed?
questions.explanation: Dame Ellen MacArthur(1976-) is a yachtswoman and in 2004 became the fastest person to sail around the world singlehanded.

questions.question_text: When did the First World War end?
questions.explanation: The First World War ended at 11.00 amon the 11th November 1918with victory for Britain and its allies.

questions.question_text: What are Welsh cakes made of?

answers.text: Bacon, eggs, sausage, black pudding and potato bread

questions.explanation: Welsh cakes are a traditional Welsh snack made fromflour, dried fruits and spices, and served either hot or cold.

questions.question_text: Where is the London Eye situated?

answers.text: On the northern bank of the River Thames
On the southern bank of the River Thames
On the northern bank of the River Lea
On the southern bank of the River Lea

questions.explanation: The London Eye is situatedon the southern bank of the River Thamesand is a Ferris wheel that is 443 feet (135 metres) tall.

questions.question_text: What is the relationship between the monarch and the government?

answers.text: Approve the government’s decisions on government policies
Advise, warn and encourage the government’s decisions
Advise, encourage and approve the government’s decisions
Advise and approve the government’s decisions

questions.explanation: The monarch has regular meetings with the Prime Minister and can advise, warn and encourage, but the decisions on government policies are made by the Prime Minister and cabinet.

questions.question_text: The UK is a ‘constitutional monarchy’:
questions.explanation: The UK has a constitutional monarchy.

questions.question_text: What do you need to apply to become a permanent resident or citizen of the UK (Choose TWO options)?

answers.text: To be able to speak and read English
A good understanding of life in the UK

questions.explanation: To apply to become a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you will need to speak and read English and have a good understanding of life in the UK.

questions.question_text: Which British scientist was awarded a Nobel Prize for discovering the structure of the DNA molecule?
questions.explanation: The structure of the DNA molecule was discovered in 1953 through work at British universities in London and Cambridge. This discovery contributed to many scientific advances, particularly in medicine and fighting crime.Francis Crick(1916-2004), one of those awarded the Nobel Prize for this discovery, was British.

questions.question_text: Who established the Church of England?
questions.explanation: To divorce his first wife,Henry VIIIneeded the approval of the Pope. When the Pope refused, Henry established the Church of England. In this new church, the king, not the Pope, would have the power to appoint bishops and order how people should worship.

questions.question_text: When does Lent take place?
questions.explanation: The40 days before Easterare known as Lent. It is a time when Christians take time to reflect and prepare for Easter.

questions.question_text: Which of the following national galleries is NOT located in London?
questions.explanation: The National Museum is located in Cardiff, Wales.

questions.question_text: How much can you be fined if you watch TV but do not have a TV licence?
questions.explanation: You will receive a fineup to £1,000if you watch TV but do not have a TV licence.

questions.question_text: How old is the clock at the Houses of Parliament in London, also known as ‘Big Ben’?
questions.explanation: Big Ben is the nickname for the great bell of the clock at the House of Parliament in London. The clock is over150 years oldand is a popular tourist attraction.

questions.question_text: The UK was a full member of the European Union but did not use the Euro currency.
questions.explanation: This statement istrue.

questions.question_text: The North Atlantic Treaty Organisation is a group of European and North American countries that was created with which TWO purposes:

answers.text: Protect and promote human rights in those countries
Help each other if they come under attack
Maintain peace between all its members
Promote free trade amongst those countries

questions.explanation: NATO is a group of European and North American countries that have agreed to help each other if they come under attack. It also aims to maintain peace between all of its members.

questions.question_text: The small claims procedure is used in England and Wales for minor disputes for:
questions.explanation: This procedure is used forclaims of less than £10,000in England and Wales and £3,000 in Scotland and Northern Ireland.

questions.question_text: What name is given to the period in the 18th century when new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed?
questions.explanation: During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed. This is often called ‘the Enlightenment’.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of ‘Magna Carta’?
questions.explanation: The Magna Carta (which meansthe Great Charter). The Magna Carta established the idea that even the king was subject to the law. It protected the rights of the nobility and restricted the king’s power to collect taxes or to make and change laws.

questions.question_text: When did the Wars of the Roses end?
questions.explanation: The Wars of the Roses ended with the Battle of Bosworth Field in 1485.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the responsibility of the Chancellor of the Exchequer?
questions.explanation: The Chancellor of the Exchequer is responsible for the economy.

questions.question_text: In which British university did Isaac Newton study?
questions.explanation: Isaac Newton studiedat Cambridge University.

questions.question_text: Who invaded England after the Romans?
questions.explanation: The Roman army left Britain in AD 410 to defend other parts of the Roman Empire and never returned. Britain was again invaded by tribes from northern Europe: the Jutes, the Angles and the Saxons.

questions.question_text: When did people learn to make bronze?
questions.explanation: Around 4,000 years ago, people learned to make bronze. We call this period the Bronze Age.

questions.question_text: When is the Jewish celebration known as Hanukkah normally celebrated?
questions.explanation: Hanukkah is inNovember or Decemberand is celebrated for eight days.

questions.question_text: What musical award is given during the Mercury Music Prize?

questions.question_text: Who was Boudicca?

questions.question_text: Which TWO of the following water sports are popular in the UK?
questions.explanation: Sailing continues to be popular in the UK, reflecting its maritime heritage. Rowing is also popular, both as a leisure activity and as a competitive sport.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements is TRUE?

answers.text: Forcing another person to marry is a civil offence
Forcing another person to marry is a criminal offence
Forcing another person to marry is not punished in the UK
Forcing another person to marry is common in the UK

questions.question_text: In the UK, what should dogs wear in public places?

answers.text: A collar with the name and address of the owner
A collar with the name of the dog
A tracking device in case they get lost
Clothes to avoid the cold in the winter

questions.question_text: Where do UK residents need to register their car or motorcycle?

questions.explanation: If you are resident in the UK, your car or motor cycle must be registered at the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA).

questions.question_text: Popular social networking websites in the UK include:

questions.question_text: According to the 2011 Census, what percentage of the population identified themselves as Muslim?
questions.explanation: In the 2011 Census, 59% of people identified themselves as Christian. Much smaller proportions identified themselves as Muslim (4.8%), Hindu (1.5%), Sikh (0.8%), Jewish or Buddhist (both less than 0.5%).

questions.question_text: How often are elections held for the Welsh government?
questions.explanation: The Welsh government has 60 Senedd members (SMs) and elections are held every four years using a form of proportional representation.

questions.question_text: Who was the British Minister after Margaret Thatcher?
questions.explanation: John Major was Prime Minister after Mrs Thatcher, and helped establish the Northern Ireland peace process.

questions.question_text: What name is given to the person appointed by local authorities to be the ceremonial leader of a particular council?
questions.explanation: Many local authorities appoint amayor, who is the ceremonial leader of the council. In some towns, a mayor is elected to be the effective leader of the administration.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of the term ‘first past the post’?

answers.text: In each constituency, the candidate who gets the most votes is elected
If no political party wins a majority, two parties may join and govern together
If an MP dies or resigns, there will be a fresh election
The Speaker will be chosen by other MPs in a secret ballot

questions.explanation: MPs are elected through a system called ‘first past the post’. In each constituency, the candidate who gets the most votes is elected.

questions.question_text: Who defeated Emperor Napoleon at the Battle of Waterloo in 1815?
questions.explanation: In 1815, the French Wars ended with the defeat of the Emperor Napoleon bythe Duke of Wellingtonat the Battle of Waterloo.

questions.question_text: Which court deals with the MOST serious cases in Scotland, such as murder?
questions.explanation: In Scotland, serious cases are heard in a Sheriff Court with either a sheriff or a sheriff with a jury. Themost serious casesin Scotland, such as murder, are heard at aHigh Courtwith a judge and jury.

questions.question_text: What was the symbol of the House of Tudor?

answers.text: A red rose with a white rose inside it
A white rose with a red rose inside it

questions.explanation: The symbol of the House of Tudor was a red rose with a white rose inside it as a sign that the Houses of York and Lancaster were now allies.

questions.question_text: What animal is represented in the Welsh flag?
questions.explanation: There is also an official Welsh flag, which shows a Welshdragon. The Welsh dragon does not appear on the Union Flag because, when the first Union Flag was created in 1606 from the flags of Scotland and England, the Principality of Wales was already untied with England.

questions.question_text: Which famous economist developed ideas about economics during the 18th century and which are still referred to today?
questions.explanation: During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed. This is often called ‘the Enlightenment’. Many of the great thinkers of the Enlightenment were Scottish.Adam Smithdeveloped ideas about economics which are still referred to today.

questions.explanation: Britain continues to be particularly strong in special effects and animation movies.

questions.question_text: Which British artist was a portrait painter who often painted people in country or garden scenarios?
questions.explanation: Thomas Gainsborough (1727-88) was a portrait painter who often painted people in country or garden scenery.

questions.question_text: Which court deals with minor criminal cases in England, Wales and Northern Ireland?

questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, most minor criminal cases are dealt with in a Magistrates’ Court. In Scotland, minor criminal offences go to a Justice of the Peace Court.

questions.question_text: What name is given to the tombs where people buried their dead during the Bronze Age?
questions.explanation: During the Bronze Age people lived in roundhouses and buried their dead in tombs calledround barrows.

questions.question_text: The Northern Ireland Assembly cannot make decisions on:

questions.question_text: What is the first verse of the National Anthem of the UK ‘God save the King’?
questions.explanation: The first verse of the National Anthem of the UK is ‘God save our gracious King!.

questions.explanation: Radioactivity is not a British invention.

questions.question_text: Which British Prime Minister was famous for the speech ‘I have nothing to offer but blood, toil, tears and sweat’?
questions.explanation: During the Second World War, Winston Churchill made many famous speeches including lines which you may still hear:  ‘I have nothing to offer but blood, toil, tears and sweat’. This was Churchill’s first speech to the House of Commons after he became Prime Minister, 1940.

questions.question_text: Which of the following countries did NOT belong to the Allies during World War I?

questions.question_text: What is the money from TV licences used for?

answers.text: To pay for the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC)

questions.explanation: The money from TV licences is used to pay for the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC). This is a public service broadcaster providing television and radio programmes. The BBC is the largest broadcaster in the world. It is the only wholly state-funded media organisation that is independent of government.

questions.question_text: Members of the Welsh government are elected every four years on the basis of:

answers.text: First past the post system (the candidate who gets the most votes)

questions.explanation: The Welsh government and the Senedd are based in Cardiff, the capital city of Wales. There are 60 members of the Senedd (SMs) and elections are held every four years using a form of proportional representation.

questions.question_text: What is the Commonwealth?

answers.text: An association of countries that support each other and work together towards shared goals in democracy and development
An organisation responsible for the protection and promotion of human rights in its member countries
An association of countries that promotes international peace and security
A group of European and North American countries that have agreed to help each other if they come under attack

questions.explanation: The Commonwealth is an association of countries that support each other and work together towards shared goals in democracy and development. Most member states were once part of the British Empire, although a few countries which were not have also joined.

questions.question_text: Which famous architect designed St Paul’s Cathedral after it was destroyed by a fire in 1666?
questions.explanation: In 1666, a great fire destroyed much of the city of London, including many churches and St Paul’s Cathedral. London was rebuilt with a new St Paul’s, which was designed by a famous architect, Sir Christopher Wren.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a fundamental principle of life in the UK?

answers.text: Intolerance of those with different beliefs

questions.explanation: The fundamental principles of British life include: democracy, the rule of law, individual liberty, tolerance of those with different faiths and beliefs and participation in community life.

questions.explanation: Mozambique.

questions.question_text: Who has to pay national insurance contributions in the UK?

questions.question_text: What do Ian McEwan, Hilary Mantel and Julian Barnes have in common?

answers.text: They were awarded with the Man Booker Prize for Fiction

questions.question_text: In Northern Ireland members of the Legislative Assembly are elected on the basis of:

questions.question_text: How can MPs be contacted (choose TWO options)?

questions.question_text: What did the’Bill of Rights’ confirm in 1689?

answers.text: The rights of Parliament and the limits of the king’s power
The supreme power of the king

questions.explanation: The Bill of Rights, 1689, confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the king’s power. Parliament took control of who could be monarch and declared that the king or queen must be a Protestant.

questions.question_text: Who designed the Clifton Suspension Bridge located over the Avon George?

questions.question_text: Does Britain have a written constitution?

questions.question_text: What was the estimated population of the British Empire during the Victorian period?
questions.explanation: During the Victorian period, the British Empire grew to cover all of India, Australia and large parts of Africa. It became the largest empire the world has ever seen, with an estimated population of more than 400 million people.

questions.question_text: Which two languages combined form the basis of the English language?
questions.explanation: After the Norman Conquest, the king and his noblemen had spoken Norman French and the peasants had continued to speak Anglo-Saxon. Gradually these two languages combined to become one English language.

questions.question_text: Which THREE of the following are known to be main parts of the British government?
questions.explanation: In the UK, there are several different parts of government. The main ones are: the monarchy, the Parliament (the House of Commons and the House of Lords),  the Prime Minister, the cabinet, the judiciary (courts), the police, the civil service and the local government.

questions.question_text: When were Protection Orders to protect a person from being forced into a marriage introduced in Scotland?

Court orders can be obtained to protect a person from being forced into a marriage, or to protect a person in a forced marriage. Similar Protection Orders were introduced in Scotland inNovember 2011.

questions.explanation: The Roman army left Britain inAD 410to defend other parts of the Roman Empire and never returned.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements is true?

questions.question_text: Emmeline Pankhurst set up the women’s Franchise League in 1889, which fought to get the vote in local elections for married women.

questions.question_text: The king is the head of state in the UK:

The leader of the House of Leeds

questions.question_text: How can you visit the Northern Ireland Assembly (choose TWO options)?

questions.question_text: When was the first television broadcast made?

questions.question_text: When was the National Health System (NHS) established?

questions.question_text: The King has reigned since her mother’s death in 2022.

questions.question_text: What is celebrated during Diwali?

The victory of good over evil and the gaining of knowledge
The founding of the Sikh community known as the Khalsa
The beginning of the winter season

questions.question_text: Who chairs the debates in the House of Commons?
questions.explanation: Debates in the House of Commons are chaired bythe Speaker.

questions.explanation: The Battle of Hastings is commemorated in a great piece of embroidery, known asthe Bayeux tapestry, which can still be seen in France today.

questions.explanation: False. Anyone who is violent towards their partner – whether they are a man or a woman, married or living together – can be prosecuted.

questions.question_text: Which golf ‘Major’ tournament is hosted by a different golf course every year?

questions.question_text: Which act introduced the Forced Marriage Protection Orders for England, Wales and Northern Ireland in 2008?
questions.explanation: Forced Marriage Protection Orders were introduced in 2008 for England, Wales and Northern Ireland underthe Forced Marriage (Civil Protection) Act 2007. Similar Protection Orders were introduced in Scotland in November 2011.

questions.question_text: Which of the following countries did NOT join the European Economic Community when it was first formed in 1957?
questions.explanation: West Germany, France, Belgium, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands formed the European Economic Community (EEC) in 1957. At firstthe UKdid not wish to join the EEC but it eventually did so in 1973.

questions.question_text: How many members does the Northern Ireland assembly have?
questions.explanation: The Northern Ireland Assembly has90 elected members, known as MLAs (members of the Legislative Assembly). They are elected with a form of proportional representation.

questions.question_text: Which of the following civil laws include disputes between landlords and tenants over issues such as repairs and eviction?

questions.question_text: How can you visit the Scottish Parliament?

answers.text: Arranging a tour through the visitor services

questions.explanation: To visit the Scottish Parliament, you can get information, book tickets or arrange tours through visitor services. You can also write to them at the Scottish Parliament, Edinburgh, EH99 1SP, telephone 0131 348 5200 or email sp.booking@scottish.parliament.

questions.question_text: Which of the following gardens is located in Wales?
questions.explanation: There are famous gardens to visit throughout the UK, including Kew Gardens, Sissinghurst and Hidcote in England, Crathes Castle and Inveraray Castle in Scotland,Bodnant Gardenin Wales, and Mount Stewart in Northern Ireland.

questions.question_text: Who was reining in Britain when the British Empire became the largest empire the world has ever seen, with an estimated population of more than 400 million people?
questions.explanation: During the Victorian period, the British Empire grew to cover all of India, Australia and large parts of Africa. It became the largest empire the world has ever seen, with an estimated population of more than 400 million people.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a duty of the police?
questions.explanation: The job of the police in the UK is to protect life and property, prevent disturbances (also known as keeping the peace) and prevent and detect crime.

questions.question_text: The UK is not part of which of the following international institutions?
questions.explanation: The UK is a member of the Council of Europe, the United Nations and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO). The UK is no longer a member of the European Union.

questions.question_text: Where is the National Gallery of Scotland located?
questions.explanation: The National Gallery of Scotland isin Edinburgh.

questions.question_text: Where are the ancestors of the first farmers to arrive in Britain believed to come from?
questions.explanation: The first farmers arrived in Britain 6,000 years ago. The ancestors of these first farmers probably came fromsouth-east Europe.

questions.question_text: What religion did Elizabeth I follow?
questions.explanation: Queen Elizabeth I was aProtestant.

questions.question_text: Who directed the movie ‘Chariots of Fire’ in 1981?

questions.question_text: What do new citizens have to swear or affirm as part of the citizenship ceremony?

They will go to church at least once a week

questions.question_text: In which TWO cases may a person who has been summoned to do jury service be exempted from doing it:

If they provide a good reason to be excused, such as ill health

questions.explanation: Everyone who is summoned to do jury service must do it unless they are not eligible (for example, because they have a criminal conviction) or they provide a good reason to be excused, such as ill health.

questions.question_text: What is the role of the shadow cabinet?

To challenge the government and put forward alternative policies

questions.explanation: Incorrect The role of the shadow cabinet is to challenge the government and put forward alternative policies.

questions.question_text: Which hill fort from the Iron Age can be seen in the county of Dorset?

questions.question_text: On which of the following issues the Northern Ireland Assembly CANNOT make decisions?
questions.explanation: The Northern Ireland Assembly can make decisions on issues such as education, agriculture, the environment, health and social services.

questions.question_text: Who was the first person to sail single-handed around the world in 1966/67?
questions.explanation: A British sailor,Sir Francis Chichester, was the first person to sail singlehanded around the world, in 1966/67.

questions.question_text: In 1837, Queen Victoria became queen of the UK at the age of 20.
questions.explanation: In 1837, Queen Victoria became queen of the UKat the age of 18.

questions.question_text: Who led the group of Catholics who tried to kill the Protestant king with a bomb in the Houses of the Parliament in 1605?
questions.explanation: In 1605, a group of Catholics led byGuy Fawkesfailed in their plan to kill the Protestant king with a bomb in the Houses of Parliament. This is the origin of the Bonfire Night celebration on the 5th November, when people in Great Britain set off fireworks at home or in special displays.

questions.question_text: What was the biggest source of employment in Britain before the 18th century?
questions.explanation: Before the 18th century,agriculturewas the biggest source of employment in Britain.

questions.question_text: In which city is the Scottish Parliament building, also known as Holyrood, located?

questions.question_text: The UK continues to be a world leader in the development and manufacture of motor-sport technology:

questions.question_text: Why was the ‘Habeas Corpus Act’ of 1679 an important piece of legislation?

answers.text: It allowed people over 21 years old to vote
It guaranteed that no one could be held prisoner unlawfully
It abolished slavery throughout the British Empire
It abolished a number of taxes on imported goods in the UK

questions.explanation: The Habeas Corpus Act became law in 1679. This was a very important piece of legislation which remains relevant today. The Act guaranteed that no one could be held prisoner unlawfully. Every prisoner has a right to a court hearing.

questions.question_text: What British artist was awarded the Turner Prize?
questions.explanation: Damien Hirst.

questions.question_text: How many members has the Council of Europe?
questions.explanation: The Council of Europe is separated from the EU. It has47 member countries, including the UK, and is responsible for the protection and promotion of human rights in those countries.

questions.question_text: In the UK, Members of the Parliament (MPs) are elected on the basis of:

answers.text: First past the post system (the candidate who gets the most votes)

questions.explanation: MPs are elected through a system called‘first past the post’. In  constituency, the candidate who gets the most votes is elected.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements regarding television in Northern Ireland is TRUE?

answers.text: Some programmes are broadcasted in Irish Gaelic
All programmes are broadcasted in English
There are no specific programmes to Northern Ireland

questions.explanation: There are programmes specific to Northern Ireland and some programmes broadcast in Irish Gaelic.

questions.question_text: In the second half of the 19th century there was an important group of artists who painted detailed pictures on religious or literary themes in bright colours. These were known as:
questions.explanation: The Pre-Raphaeliteswere an important group of artists in the second half of the 19th century. They painted detailed pictures on religious or literary themes in bright colours. The group included Holman Hunt, Dante Gabriel Rossetti and Sir John Millais.

questions.question_text: The Muslim festival known as Eid ul Adha reminds Muslims of their own commitment to God:
questions.explanation: Eid ul Adha reminds Muslims of their own commitment to God.

questions.question_text: What was the population of the UK in 1901?
questions.explanation: The population of the UK in 1901 was40 million people.

questions.question_text: People in the UK do NOT have to pay tax on:
questions.explanation: People in the UK have to pay tax on their income, which includes: wages from paid employment, profits from self-employment, taxable benefits, pensions and income from property, savings and dividends.

questions.question_text: Which British scientist co-invented the MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) scanner?
questions.explanation: Sir Peter Mansfield(1933-), a British scientist, is the co-inventor of the MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) scanner. This enables doctors and researchers to obtain exact and non-invasive images of human internal organs and has revolutionised diagnostic medicine.

questions.question_text: Which political party called a referendum on the UK’s membership of the European Union?
questions.explanation: The Conservative governmentcalled a referendum on the UK’s membership of the European Union.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a popular area for walkers?
questions.explanation: Parts ofHadrian’s Wall, including the forts of Housesteads and Vindolanda is a popular area for walkers and is a UNESCO (United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organization) World Heritage Site.

questions.question_text: When did hereditary peers lose the automatic right to attend the House of Lords?
questions.explanation: Since1999, hereditary peers have lost the automatic right to attend the House of Lords. They now elect a few of their number to represent them in the House of Lords.

questions.question_text: Which charity works for the preservation of buildings in England?
questions.explanation: In the UK, many parts of the countryside and places of interest are kept open bythe National Trustin England, Wales and Northern Ireland and the National Trust for Scotland. Both are charities that work to preserve important buildings, coastline and countryside in the UK.

questions.question_text: What name is given to the new social classes that appeared after the Black Death plague and who owned large areas of land?
questions.explanation: Following the Black Death, the smaller population meant there was less need to grow cereal crops. There were labour shortages and peasants began to demand higher wages. New social classes appeared, including owners of large areas of land (later calledthe gentry), and people left the countryside to live in the towns. In the towns, growing wealth led to the development of a strong middle class.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a traditional Welsh food?
questions.explanation: Welsh cakesare a traditional Welsh snack made from flour, dried fruits and spices, and served either hot or cold.

questions.question_text: Which of the following was one of the most famous battles of the Hundred Years War?
questions.explanation: One of the most famous battles of the Hundred Years War wasthe Battle of Agincourtin 1415, where King Henry V’s vastly outnumbered English army defeated the French. The English left France in the 1450s.

questions.question_text: During the Middle Ages, England was an important trading nation and people came to England from abroad to trade and also to work. Where did the engineers come from?
questions.explanation: During the Middle Ages, people came to England from abroad to trade and also to work. Many had special skills, such as weavers from France, engineers fromGermany, glass manufacturers from Italy and canal builders from Holland.

questions.question_text: Who was the captain of the English football team that won the World Cup in 1966?
questions.explanation: Bobby Moore(1941-93) captained the English football team that won the World Cup in 1966.

questions.question_text: Membership to the Commonwealth  is compulsory for its members:
questions.explanation: Membership to the Commonwealth is voluntary.

questions.question_text: How many verdicts are possible in trials in Scotland?
questions.explanation: The jury has to listen to the evidence presented at the trial and then decide a verdict of ‘guilty’ or ‘not guilty’ based of what they have heard. In Scotland, a third verdict of ‘not proven’ is also possible.

questions.question_text: How many wives did Henry VIII have?
questions.explanation: Henry VIII hadsix wives.

questions.question_text: Which of the following charities works with sick animals?
questions.explanation: ThePDSAis the People’s Dispensary for Sick Animals.

questions.explanation: The Home Secretary is responsible forcrime, policing and immigration.

questions.question_text: Which of the following sports can be traced as far back as the Roman times?
questions.explanation: There is a very long history ofhorse racingin Britain, with evidence of events taking place as far back as Roman times.

questions.question_text: When did the English become the preferred language of the royal court and Parliament?
questions.explanation: By1400, in England, official documents were being written in English, and English had become the preferred language of the royal court and Parliament.

questions.question_text: When is St Andrews Day, patron saint of Scotland?
questions.explanation: St Andrews Day, patron saint of Scotland, is celebrated on the30th of November.

questions.question_text: Which organisation has been organising ‘The Proms’ since 1927?
questions.explanation: The Proms is an eight-week summer season of orchestral classical music that takes place in various venues, including the Royal Albert Hall in London. It has been in various venues, including the Royal Albert Hall in London. It has been organised bythe British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC)since 1927.

questions.question_text: Which of the following organisations has no power to make laws but draws up conventions and charters, including the European Convention on Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms?
questions.explanation: The Council of Europeis responsible for the protection and promotion of human rights in those countries. It has no power to make laws but draws up conventions and charters, the most well-known of which is the European Convention on Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms, usually called the European Convention on Human Rights.

questions.question_text: Where is Snowdonia National Park located?
questions.explanation: Snowdonia is a national park inNorth Wales.

questions.question_text: What actions did Henry VII take after his victory in the Wars of the Roses?

answers.text: Reduced the power of the nobles
Broke away with the Church of Rome
Increased the power of the nobles

questions.explanation: After his victory in the Wars of the Roses, Henry VII wanted to make sure that England remained peaceful and that his position as king was secure. He deliberately strengthened the central administration of England and reduced the power of the nobles.

questions.question_text: Which Court deals with the most serious civil cases in Scotland?

questions.explanation: The leader of the opposition leads his or her party in pointing out what they see asthe government’s failures and weaknesses.

questions.question_text: Who became Prime Minister of the UK in May 2010?
questions.explanation: In May 2010, and for the first time in the UK since February 1974, no political party won an overall majority in the General Election. The Conservative and Liberal Democrat parties formed a coalition and the leader of the Conservative Party,David Cameron, became Prime Minister.

questions.question_text: The Reform Act of 1832 abolished the old pocket and rotten boroughs.
questions.explanation: This statement istrue.

questions.question_text: What is the minimum age requirement to drive a moped in the UK?
questions.explanation: You need to be at least16years old to ride a moped, and there are other age requirements and special tests for driving large vehicles.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements is true?

Great Britain refers only to England, Northern Ireland and Scotland, not to Wales.
Great Britain refers to England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.
Great Britain refers only to England, Scotland and Wales, not to Northern Ireland.

questions.question_text: How many countries formed the European Economic Community (EEC) when it was first created in 1957?
questions.explanation: The European Economic Community (EEC), was set up bysixwestern European countries (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands) who signed the Treaty of Rome on 25 March 1957.

questions.question_text: Northern Ireland and Wales have their own banknotes, which are valid everywhere in the UK. However, shop and businesses do not have to accept them:
questions.explanation: Northern Ireland and Scotlandhave their own banknotes, which are valid everywhere in the UK. However, shops and businesses do not have to accept them.

questions.question_text: What is donated blood used for?

answers.text: To help people with a wide range of injuries and illnesses
Blood cannot be donated in the UK
To carry out research with your DNA
To be stored in the hospital in case you need it in the future

questions.explanation: Donated blood is used by hospitalsto help people with a wide range of injuries and illnesses.

questions.question_text: How often are the general elections held in the UK?

questions.explanation: One of the tribal leaders whofought against the Romanswas Boudicca, the queen of the Iceni in what is now eastern England.

questions.question_text: When was the hovercraft invented?
questions.explanation: Sir Christopher Cockerell (1910-99), a British inventor, invented the hovercraftin the 1950s.

questions.explanation: Macbeth is a famous play byWilliam Shakespeare.

questions.explanation: In 1996, two British scientists, Sir Ian Wilmot (1944-) and Keith Campbell (1954-2012), led a team which was the first to succeed in cloning a mammal, Dolly thesheep.

questions.question_text: What is the name of the building where the Northern Ireland Assembly meet?
questions.explanation: The Northern Ireland Assembly building is known asStormont.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a function of the House of Lords?

answers.text: Check laws that have been passed by the House of Commons

The House of Lords checks laws that have been passed by the House of Commons to ensure they are fit for purpose. questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a World Heritage Site?

questions.question_text: When was the Giant’s Causeway formed?

questions.question_text: Who was the first person to sail single-handed around the world without stopping?

questions.question_text: What British writer created the fictional detective Sherlock Holmes?
questions.explanation: Sir Arthur Conan Doylewas a Scottish doctor and writer. He was best known for his stories about Sherlock Holmes, who was one of the first fictional detectives.

questions.question_text: How can you visit the  Senedd?

questions.question_text: How were Elizabeth I and ‘Mary, Queen of Scots’ related?

questions.question_text: Choose the correct answer. The Middle Ages were:

answers.text: A period of peace in Britain

A period where new ideas about politics and philosophy were introduced in Britain

questions.explanation: The Middle Ages (or the medieval period) was a time of almostconstant war.

questions.question_text: What does the NATO stand for?
questions.explanation: NATO stands forThe North Atlantic Treaty Organisation.

questions.question_text: What characterised the people from the Bronze Age?

answers.text: They were farmers who lived in large villages

questions.explanation: The people of the Bronze Agewere accomplished metalworkerswho made many beautiful objects in bronze and gold, including tools, ornaments and weapons.

questions.question_text: Where is the National Horseracing Museum located?
questions.explanation: The National Horseracing Museum is located inNewmarket, Suffolk.

questions.question_text: In which of the following matters the Scottish Parliament CANNOT legislate?
questions.explanation: The matters on which the Scottish Parliament can legislate include: civil and criminal law, health, education, planning and additional tax-raising powers.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a popular showcase of mainly theatre and comedy performances and the biggest and most well-known festival that takes place during the Edinburgh Festival?
questions.explanation: The Fringeis a showcase of mainly theatre and comedy performances. It often shows experimental work.The biggest and most well-known being the Edinburgh Festival Fringe.

questions.question_text: Does Britain have a constitutional monarchy?

questions.question_text: Who defeated the French at the battle of Agincourt in 1415?
questions.explanation: One of the most famous battles of the Hundred Years War was the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, whereKing Henry V’s vastly outnumbered English army defeated the French.

questions.question_text: Which is the most famous tennis tournament hosted in Britain and which takes place each year at the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club?
questions.explanation: The most famous tournament hosted in Britain isThe Wimbledon Championships, which takes place each year at the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club.

questions.question_text: What is the minimum age required for a citizen to stand for public office?

questions.question_text: Who makes sure that the opposition has a guaranteed amount of time to debate issues which it chooses during political debates?

questions.explanation: If your driving licence if from a country in the European Union (EU), Iceland, Liechtenstein or Norway, you can drive in the UK for as long as your licence is valid.

questions.question_text: Which British Prime Minister nationalized major industries including coal and steel?
questions.explanation: Clement Attlee’s government undertook the nationalisation of major industries (like coal and steel), created the National Health Service and implemented many of Beveridge’s plans for a stronger welfare state. Attlee also introduced measures to improve the conditions of workers.

questions.question_text: Who was the first Archbishop of Canterbury?

questions.question_text: What is the money raised from the Income Tax used for (choose THREE options)?
questions.explanation: Money raised from income tax pays for government services such asroads, education, police and the armed forces.

questions.question_text: What name is given to the clock tower at the Houses of Parliament in honour of Queen Elizabeth II’s Diamond Jubilee in 2012?
questions.explanation: The clock tower at the Houses of Parliament in London is named‘Elizabeth Tower’in honour of Queen Elizabeth II’s Diamond Jubilee in 2012.

questions.question_text: When were the Forced Marriage Protection Orders introduced for England, Wales and Northern Ireland, which aimed at protecting a person from being forced into a marriage, or to protect a person in a forced marriage?
questions.explanation: Forced Marriage Protection Orders were introduced in2008for England, Wales and Northern Ireland under the Forced Marriage (Civil Protection) Act 2007.

questions.question_text: Whose details are NOT listed in the Phone Book?
questions.explanation: MPs, Senedd members (SMs) and members of the Scottish Parliament (MSPs) are also listed in The Phone Book, published by BT. The King is not.

questions.question_text: Which of the following words comes from the Norman French?
questions.explanation: Some words in modern English – for example, ‘park’ and‘beauty’– are based on Norman French words.

questions.question_text: How are the official reports where the Parliament’s proceedings are published called?
questions.explanation: Proceedings in Parliament are broadcast on television and published in official reports calledHansard.

questions.question_text: How many Senedd members does the Welsh government have?
questions.explanation: The Welsh government has60 Senedd members(SMs) and elections are held every four years using a form of proportional representation.

questions.question_text: Catherine Parr, the sixth wife of Henry VIII, was a cousin of Anne Boleyn:
questions.explanation: Catherine Howard was a cousin of Anne Boleyn.

questions.question_text: Who deals with cases involving personal injury, family matters, breaches of contract and divorce in Scotland?
questions.explanation: County Courts deal with a wide range of civil disputes. These include people trying to get back money that is owed to them, cases involving personal injury, family matters, breaches of contract, and divorce. In Scotland, most of these matters are dealt with inthe Sheriff Court.

questions.question_text: What was the symbol of York during the Wars of the Roses?
questions.explanation: The symbol of York during the Wars of the Roses wasa white rose.

questions.question_text: According to the 2011 Census, what percentage of the population identified themselves as Jewish?
questions.explanation: According to the 2011 Census,less than 0.5%of people identify themselves as Jewish.

questions.question_text: During which movement the Parliament passed laws giving women the right to equal pay and made it illegal for employees to discriminate against women because of their gender:
questions.explanation: The Swinging Sixtieswas a time when the Parliament passed new laws giving women the right to equal pay and made it illegal for employers to discriminate against women because of their gender.

questions.question_text: What name is given to the members of the House of Lords?
questions.explanation: Members of the House of Lords, known aspeers, are not elected by the people and do not represent a constituency.

questions.question_text: Where can you find a statue of Boudicca, the queen of the Iceni and one of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans?
questions.explanation: There is a statue of Boudicca, the queen of the Iceni, onWestminster Bridgein London, near the Houses of Parliament.

questions.question_text: Which of the following castles is located in Scotland?
questions.explanation: Crathes Castleand Inveraray Castle are located in Scotland.

questions.question_text: For how long was Britain a republic under the leadership of Oliver Cromwell?
questions.explanation: Britain was a republic under the leadership of Oliver Cromwell for11 years.

questions.question_text: Magistrates and Justices of the Peace (JPs) are members of:
questions.explanation: Magistrates and Justices of the Peace (JPs) are members ofthe local community.

questions.question_text: Which British explorer mapped the coast of Australia?
questions.explanation: Captain James Cookmapped the coast of Australia and a few colonies were established there.

questions.question_text: How many members does a jury have in Scotland?
questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland a jury has 12 members, and in Scotland a jury has15 members.

questions.question_text: Who can get a 50% discount on their TV licences?
questions.explanation: People over 75 can apply for a free TV licence andblind peoplecan get a 50% discount.

questions.question_text: Which British city is famous for its celebration of Diwali?
questions.explanation: There is a famous celebration of Diwali inLeicester.

questions.question_text: Which of the following British actresses has NOT won an Oscar?

questions.question_text: Which of the following sports has a long association with royalty?
questions.explanation: Horse racinghas a long association with royalty.

questions.question_text: Hanukkah is a Jewish festival celebrated to remember the Jews’ struggle for religious freedom.
questions.explanation: Hanukkah is in November or December and is celebrated for eight days. It is to remember the Jews’ struggle for religious freedom.

questions.question_text: How can you visit the Northern Ireland Assembly (choose TWO options)?

answers.text: Arranging a tour through the visitor services

questions.explanation: There are two ways to arrange a visit to the Northern Ireland Assembly at Stormont. You can eithercontact the Education Service(details are on the Northern Ireland Assembly website at http://www.niassembly.gov.uk)or contact an MLA.

questions.question_text: Most citizens of the UK, the Irish republic or the Commonwealth aged 18 or over can stand for public office, except for (choose THREE options):

answers.text: People found guilty of certain criminal offences

questions.explanation: Members of the Commonwealth aged 18 or over can stand for public office. There are some exceptions, including:members of the armed forces, civil servants and people found guilty of certain criminal offences.

questions.question_text: What were the main occupations of the people during the Iron Age?
questions.explanation: During the Iron Age most people werefarmers, craft workers or warriors.

questions.question_text: To look after yourself and your family is one of the responsibilities that you will have as a permanent resident or citizen of the UK.
questions.explanation: This statement isTRUE.

answers.text: The Church of the United Kingdom
