questions.question_text: Where does the Scottish Parliament sit?
questions.explanation: In Scotland the elected members, called MSPs, meet in the Scottish Parliament building at Holyrood inEdinburgh.

questions.question_text: Who became one of the most popular monarchs in English history, particularly after 1588, when the English defeated the Spanish Armada?
questions.explanation: Elizabeth Ibecame one of the most popular monarchs in English history, particularly after 1588, when the English defeated the Spanish Armada (a large fleet of ships), which had been sent by Spain to conquer England and restore Catholicism.

questions.question_text: What was the population of the UK in 1700?
questions.explanation: The population of the UK in 1700 was5 million people.

questions.question_text: When did the ‘Concorde’ aircraft retired from service?
When did the Allies defeat Germany marking the end of the Second World War?
questions.explanation: Following victory on the beaches of Normandy, the allied forces pressed on through France and eventually into Germany. The Allies comprehensively defeated Germanyin May 1945.

questions.question_text: How many square miles does Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park cover?
questions.explanation: Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park covers720 square miles(1,865 square kilometres) in the west of Scotland.

questions.question_text: Which British athlete won 16 medals, including 11 gold medals, in races over five Paralympic Games?
questions.explanation: Baroness Tanni Grey-Thompson(1969-) is an athlete who uses a wheelchair and won 16 Paralympic medals, including 11 gold medals, in races over five Paralympic Games. She won the London Marathon six times and broke a total of 30 world records.

questions.question_text: When is New Year’s Eve celebrated?
questions.explanation: New Year’s Eve is celebrated on the31st of December.

questions.question_text: What is the capital city of Scotland?
questions.explanation: The capital city of Scotland isEdinburgh.

questions.question_text: What British sportsmen holds a number of English Test cricket records?
questions.explanation: Sir Ian Botham(1955-) captained the English cricket team and holds a number of English Test cricket records, both for batting and for bowling.

questions.question_text: During the Middle Ages, England was an important trading nation and people came to England from abroad to trade and also to work. Where did the weavers come from?
questions.explanation: During the Middle Ages, people came to England from abroad to trade and also to work. Many had special skills, such asweavers from France, engineers from Germany, glass manufacturers from Italy and canal builders from Holland.

questions.question_text: What was the name of Sir Francis Drake’s ship and which was one of the first to sail around the world?
questions.explanation: Sir Francis Drake, one of the commanders in the defeat of the Spanish Armada, was one of the founders of England’s naval tradition. His ship,the Golden Hind, was one of the first to sail right around (‘circumnavigate’) the world.

questions.question_text: To whom do new citizens have to swear or affirm loyalty as part of the citizenship ceremony?
questions.explanation: New citizens swear or affirm loyalty tothe Kingas part of the citizenship ceremony.

questions.question_text: Why did Henry VIII marry Anne of Cleves?
questions.explanation: Henry married Anne of Clevesfor political reasonsbut divorced her soon after.

questions.question_text: How many Formula 1 Grand Prix events are held in the UK every year?
questions.explanation: A Formula 1 Grand Prix event is held in the UK each yearand a number of British Grand Prix drivers have won the Formula 1 World Championship.

questions.question_text: How can you visit the UK Parliament (choose TWO options)?

answers.text: Arranging a tour through the visitor services
Writing to your local MP to ask for tickets
Queueing on the day at the public entrance

questions.explanation: To visit the UK Parliament, you can write to your local MP in advance to ask for tickets or you can Queue on the day at the public entrance.

questions.question_text: Forced marriage is where one or both parties do not or cannot give their consent to enter into the partnership:
questions.explanation: Forced marriage is where one or both parties do not or cannot give their consent to enter into the partnership.

questions.question_text: Northern Ireland and Scotland have their own banknotes, which are valid everywhere in the UK and shops and businesses are obliged to accept them:
questions.explanation: Northern Ireland and Scotland have their own banknotes, which are valid everywhere in the UK. However,shops and businesses do not have to accept them.

questions.question_text: How many American colonies declared their independence in 1776, stating that people had a right to establish their own governments?
questions.explanation: In 1776,13 American coloniesdeclared their independence, stating that people had a right to establish their own governments.

questions.question_text: Which TWO words come from the Viking language?
questions.explanation: Many of the Viking invaders stayed in Britain – especially in the east and north of England in an area known as the Danelaw (many place names there, such asGrimsby and Scunthorpecome from the Viking languages).

questions.question_text: Which of the following drugs is NOT illegal in the UK?

answers.text: All of the above are illegal

questions.explanation: Drugs such as heroin, cocaine, ecstasy and cannabis are illegal in the UK.

questions.question_text: How is the Speaker elected?

answers.text: By other MPs in a secret ballot
By the members of the House of Lords by proportional representation
By the members of the House of Commons in a public ballot

questions.explanation: The Speaker is chosenby other MPs in a secret ballot.

questions.question_text: Which TWO of the following are traditional British foods?
questions.explanation: Roast beef and fish and chipsare traditional British foods.

questions.question_text: When was the Northern Ireland Parliament established for the first time?
questions.explanation: A Northern Ireland Parliament was established in1922, when Ireland was divided, but it was abolished in 1972, shortly after the Troubles broke out in 1969.

questions.question_text: Throughout the 1990s, Britain played a leading role in coalition forces involved in the liberation of Kuwait, following the Iraqi invasion in 1990, and the conflict in the former Republic of Yugoslavia:
questions.explanation: This statement istrue.

questions.question_text: The ‘swinging sixties’ was a period of significant social change and it was known for its growth in:

answers.text: British fashion, cinema and popular music

questions.explanation: The decade of the 1960s was a period of significant social change. It was known as the ‘swinging sixties’. There was growth inBritish fashion, cinema and popular music.

questions.question_text: What is the name given to the system used to deal with children and young people who have committed an offence in Scotland?

answers.text: The Sheriff Court for Young Children

questions.question_text: Which prehistoric village located in northern Europe has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people live near the end of the Stone Age?
questions.explanation: Skara Braeon Orkney, off the north coast of Scotland, is the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe, and has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age.

questions.question_text: During the Middle Ages, a Parliament was developed in Scotland, which had three Houses called Estates. These were:

answers.text: The lords, the commons and the clergy
The lords, the commons and the farmers
The farmers, the blacksmiths and the clergy
The farmers, the blacksmiths and the teachers

questions.question_text: Which landscape architect designed grounds around country houses so that the landscape appeared to be natural, with grass, trees and lakes?
questions.explanation: In the 18th century,Lancelot ‘Capability’ Browndesigned the grounds around country houses so that the landscape appeared to be natural, with grass, trees and lakes. He often worked with Edwin Lutyens to design colourful gardens around the houses he designed.

questions.question_text: Which of the following scientific discoveries helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution?
questions.explanation: Scientific discoveries, such as James Watt’s work onsteam power, helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution.

questions.question_text: What is the function of the UN Security Council?

answers.text: Recommend action when there are international crises and threats to peace
Recommend humanitarian action when there are natural disasters

questions.explanation: The UN Security Council, whichrecommends action when there are international crises and threats to peace.

questions.question_text: Who were the parents of Elizabeth I?

answers.text: Henry VII and Anne of Cleves
Henry VIII and Catherine of Aragon

questions.explanation: Henry VIII and Anne Boleynwere the parents of Elizabeth I.

questions.explanation: This statement istrue.

questions.explanation: The Commonwealth is based on the core values of democracy, good government and the rule of law.

questions.explanation: Giving blood only takesabout an hourto do.

questions.question_text: When did the post-war economic boom come to an end?
questions.explanation: In the late 1970s, the post-war economic boom came to an end.

questions.explanation: Margaret Thatcher made structural changes to the economy through the privatisation of nationalised industries and imposed legal controls on trade union powers.

questions.question_text: Who sat at the House of Commons during the Middle Ages?

answers.text: Knights and wealthy people from towns and cities
Everyone could sit at the House of Commons

questions.question_text: Which of the following words come from the Anglo-Saxon language?
questions.explanation: The words‘Apple’ and ‘summer’are based on Anglo-Saxon words.

questions.explanation: Local authorities provide a range of services in their areas. They are funded by moneyfrom central government and by local taxes.

questions.question_text: If you are self-employed:

answers.text: You need to pay your own tax

You don’t need to pay tax
You only needed to pay tax on 50% of your earnings

questions.question_text: What name is given to the elected members of the Northern Ireland Assembly?

questions.question_text: How long does the Hanukkah celebration last for?
questions.explanation: Hanukkah is in November or December and is celebrated foreight days.

questions.question_text: What percentage of the total British population is located in Wales?

questions.question_text: Which of the following movies played an important role in boosting morale during the Second World War?
questions.explanation: During the Second World War, British movies (for example,In Which We Serve) played an important part in boosting morale.

questions.question_text: After the Black Death, the growing wealth in the towns led to the development of a strong middle class:
questions.explanation: After the Black Death, new social classes appeared, including owners of large areas of land (later called the gentry), and people left the countryside to live in the towns. In the towns, growing wealth led to the development of a strong middle class.

questions.question_text: What was the ability of the Harrier jump jet aircraft?
questions.explanation: The Harrier jump jet,an aircraft capable of taking off vertically, was also designed and developed in the UK.

questions.question_text: Who won the 2012 Olympic gold medal in heptathlon?
questions.explanation: Jessica Ennis(1986-) won the 2012 Olympic gold medal in the heptathlon, which includes seven different track and field events. She also holds a number of British athletics records.

questions.explanation: The Super Leagueis the most well-known rugby league (club) competition.

questions.question_text: Where do the Laurence Olivier Awards take place?

questions.explanation: The queen of Scotland, Mary Stuart (often now called ‘Mary, Queen of Scots’) was a Catholic. She was onlya week oldwhen her father died and she became queen.

questions.question_text: In which city is the Northern Ireland Assembly building, also known as Stormont, located?

questions.question_text: Which famous poem tells the story of the knights at the court of King Arthur?

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a fundamental principle of British life?

answers.text: Tolerance of those with different faiths and beliefs

questions.explanation: The fundamental principles of British life include: tolerance of those with different faiths and beliefs, the rule of law, democracy, individual liberty and participation in community life.

questions.question_text: Which flower is associated with Northern Ireland?
questions.explanation: The shamrockis the flower associated with Northern Ireland.

questions.question_text: The longest distance on the mainland in the UK is from John O’Groats on the north coast of Scotland to a place in the south-west corner of England known as:

questions.question_text: Who wrote a famous series of poems about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage known as ‘The Canterbury Tales’?
questions.explanation: In the years leading up to 1400,Geoffrey Chaucerwrote a series of poems in English about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage. The people decided to tell each other stories on the journey, and the poems describe the travellers and some of the stories they told. This collection of poems is called The Canterbury Tales.

questions.explanation: There are five ski centres in Scotland, as well as Europe’s longest dry ski slopenear Edinburgh.

questions.question_text: Which TWO of Henry VIII’s wives were accused of taking lovers and executed?
questions.explanation: Anne Boleyn and Catherine Howardwere accused of taking lovers and executed.

questions.question_text: Who is the head of the state in the UK?

answers.text: Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh

questions.question_text: What was the population of the UK in 1600?
questions.explanation: The population of the UK in 1600 wasjust over 4 million people.

questions.question_text: What name is given to the 31st of December in Scotland?
questions.explanation: In Scotland, 31 December is calledHogmanay.

questions.question_text: In which of the following languages is the life in the UK test NOT available?
questions.explanation: The Life in the UK test is usually taken is English, although special arrangements can be made if you wish to take it in Welsh or Scottish Gaelic.

questions.question_text: Which two scientists were successful at cloning the first mammal, Dolly the sheep?

answers.text: Sir Frank Whittle and Sir Christopher Cockrell
Sir Robert Edwards and Patrick Steptoe
Sir Ian Wilmot and Keith Campbell
Francis Creek and John Logie Baird

questions.explanation: In 1996, two British scientists,Sir Ian Wilmot and Keith Campbell, led a team which was the first to succeed in cloning a mammal, Dolly the sheep.

questions.question_text: When is the Sikh Vaisakhi festival celebrated?
questions.explanation: Vaisakhi (also spelled Baisakhi) is a Sikh festival which celebrates the founding of the Sikh community known as the Khalsa. It is celebrated on the14th of Aprileach year with parades, dancing and singing.

questions.question_text: Who were the Pre-Raphaelites?

answers.text: An important group of musicians from the 16th century
An important group who demanded the vote for the working classes
An important group of artists in the second half of the 19th century
A group of explorers who arrived in the south-east coast of Australia

questions.explanation: The Pre-Raphaelites werean important group of artists in the second half of the 19th century. They painted detailed pictures on religious or literary themes in bright colours. The group included Holman Hunt, Dante Gabriel Rossetti and Sir John Millais.

questions.question_text: When was St Pancras Station built?
questions.explanation: St Pancras Station was builtin the 19th century.

questions.question_text: Members of the Scottish Parliament (MSPs) are elected on the basis of:

answers.text: First past the post system (the candidate who gets the most votes)

questions.explanation: Members of the Scottish Parliament (MSPs) are elected by a form ofproportional representation.

questions.question_text: Which TWO of the following soap operas are popular in the UK?
questions.explanation: Popular programmes in the UK include regular soap operas such asCoronation Street and EastEnders.

questions.question_text: What does the term ‘Hansard’ relate to?

answers.text: Official reports where proceedings in Parliament are published

questions.question_text: Who was the first king of the House of Tudor?
questions.explanation: Henry VII (Henry Tudor)was the first king of the House of Tudor.

answers.text: They have won the Formula 1 World Championship

questions.question_text: According to the 2011 Census, what percentage of people said that they had no religion?

questions.question_text: During which period were the first coins produced in Britain?

questions.question_text: What other name is given to Diwali, the religious celebration that celebrates the victory of good over evil and the gaining of knowledge?
questions.explanation: Diwali normally falls in October or November and lasts for five days. It is often calledthe Festival of Lights.

questions.question_text: In Wales, the jury has to listen to the evidence presented at the trial and then decide a verdict of ‘guilty’, ‘not guilty’ or ‘not proven’ based of what they have heard:
questions.explanation: The jury has to listen to the evidence presented at the trial and then decide a verdict of ‘guilty’ or ‘not guilty’ based of what they have heard. In Scotland, a third verdict of ‘not proven’ is also possible.

questions.question_text: The Prime Minister has a country house outside London called:
questions.explanation: The Prime Minister has a country house outside London calledChequers.

questions.question_text: In which English county is Maiden Castle located?

questions.question_text: A National Insurance number does on its own prove to an employer that you have the right to work in the UK:
questions.explanation: A National Insurance number does not on its own prove to an employer that you have the right to work in the UK.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a ceremonial role to be undertaken by the King?

answers.text: Opening the new parliamentary session every year
Visiting the major cities in the UK once every six months
Giving a speech on New Year’s Eve

questions.explanation: The King has important ceremonial roles, such asthe opening of the new parliamentary session each year. On this occasion the King makes a speech which summarises the government’s policies for the year ahead.

questions.question_text: How long can you use your driving licence in the UK if you have a licence from another country?

For as long as it is valid

questions.question_text: What British discovery was influential in the development of computer science and the modern-day computer?   The Radar
questions.explanation: The Turing machineis a theoretical mathematical device invented by Alan Turing (1912-54), a British mathematician, in the 1930s. The theory was influential in the development of computer science and the modern-day computer.

questions.question_text: Which Court deals with the serious criminal offences in England, Wales and Northern Ireland?
questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, serious criminal offences are tried in front of a judge and a jury in aCrown Court.

questions.question_text: Which famous philosopher developed ideas about human nature during the 18th century and that have continued to influence philosophers over the years?
questions.explanation: During the 18th century,David Hume’s ideas about human nature continue to influence philosophers.

questions.question_text: If you are arrested and taken to a police station, a police officer should:

answers.text: Make a copy of your ID and retain you until your lawyer arrives
Tell you the reason for your arrest and that you will be able to seek legal advice
Offer you a cup of tea
Explain the law to you and wait for your family to arrive

questions.explanation: If you are arrested and taken to a police station, a police officer willtell you the reason for your arrest and you will be able to seek legal advice.

questions.question_text: Which British actor has recently won an Oscar?
questions.explanation: Recent British actors to have won Oscars include Colin Firth,Sir Antony Hopkins, Dame Judi Dench, Kate Winslet and Tilda Swinton.

questions.question_text: What TWO names are given to the day before Lent?

questions.question_text: Which of the following sports began in the UK?

questions.question_text: What did the Education Act of 1944 introduce?

questions.question_text: Which of the following tribes invaded Britain?

questions.question_text: Do you need a TV licence for watching TV on a mobile phone?
questions.explanation: Everyone in the UK with a TV, computer or other medium which can be used for watching TV must have a television licence.

questions.question_text: What do you need to apply to become a British citizen?

Have a good understanding of life in the UK

questions.question_text: The Normans used a system of land ownership known as __________.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements is TRUE?

The official name of the country is Great Britain and Southern Ireland.

The official name of the country is the United Kingdom and Great Ireland.

questions.question_text: When was slavery abolished throughout the British Empire?
questions.explanation: In 1833the Emancipation Act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire.

questions.question_text: Magistrates and Justices of the Peace (JPs) are members of the _________.
questions.explanation: Magistrates and Justices of the Peace (JPs) are members ofthe local community.

questions.question_text: Where can you find details about the small claims procedure?

questions.question_text: When is Mothering Sunday?

answers.text: The Sunday three weeks before Easter.
The Sunday three weeks after Easter.
The Sunday three weeks before Christmas.
The Sunday three weeks after Christmas.

questions.question_text: What should you do if your vehicle is over three years old?

answers.text: Take it to the MOT every year.

questions.question_text: On average, boys leave school with better qualifications than girls.

questions.question_text: When did William of Orange invade England to proclaim himself king?
questions.explanation: In 1688, important Protestants in England asked William of Orange to invade England and proclaim himself king. When William reached England, there was no resistance. James fled to France and William took over the throne, becoming William III in England, Wales and Ireland, and William II of Scotland.

questions.question_text: Which British painter is considered to be the artist who raised the profile of landscape painting?
questions.explanation: Joseph Turner(1775-1851) was an influential landscape painter in a modern style. He is considered the artist who raised the profile of landscape painting.

questions.question_text: The development of the Bessemer process during the Industrial Revolution led to the development of which two industries:
questions.explanation: The development of the Bessemer process for the mass production of steel led to the development ofthe shipbuilding industry and the railways.

questions.question_text: What is the length of the Bayeux tapestry?

questions.question_text: Which of the following countries is not a member of the Commonwealth?
questions.explanation: Costa Ricais not a member of the Commonwealth.

questions.question_text: In which of the following years did England win the World Cup?

questions.question_text: During the Battle of Trafalgar Britain fought against:
questions.explanation: Britain’s navy fought against combinedFrench and Spanish fleets, winning the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805.

questions.question_text: More women than men study at university.

questions.question_text: Why did Ireland suffer a famine in the middle of the 19th century?
questions.explanation: In the middle of the centurythe potato crop failed, and Ireland suffered a famine. A million people died from disease and starvation.

questions.question_text: What sort of battle was ‘the Battle of Britain’?

answers.text: A naval battle against the Spanish.
An aerial battle against the French.
An aerial battle against the Germans.
A naval battle against the French.

questions.explanation: Hitler wanted to invade Britain, but before sending in troops, Germany needed to control the air campaign against Britain, but the British resisted with their fighter planes and eventually won the crucialaerial battle against the Germans, called ‘the Battle of Britain’, in the summer of 1940.

questions.question_text: Who is in charge of appointing the local Chief Constable?
questions.explanation: PCCs (Police and Crime Commissioners)set local police priorities and the local policing budget. They also appoint the local Chief Constable.

questions.question_text: What does the money from the National Insurance Contributions pay for (CHOOSE TWO)?
questions.explanation: The money raised from National Insurance Contributions is used to pay for state benefits and services such as thestate retirement pension and the National Health Service (NHS).

questions.question_text: How many British died on the first day alone of the Battle of Somme?
questions.explanation: The British attack of the Somme in July 1916, resulted in about60,000 British casualtieson the first day alone.

questions.question_text: When was the first Union flag created?
questions.explanation: The first Union Flag was createdin 1606from the flags of Scotland and England, the Principality of Wales was already untied with England.

questions.question_text: Which of the following territories is not part of the UK?

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a fundamental principle of British life?
questions.explanation: The fundamental principles of British life include: democracy, the rule of law, individual liberty, tolerance of those with different faiths and beliefs and participation in community life.

questions.question_text: What do Sir Terence Conran, Clarice Cliff and Thomas Chippendale have in common?
questions.explanation: Britain has produced many greatdesigners, from Thomas Chippendale (who designed furniture in the 18th century) to Clarice Cliff (who designed Art Deco ceramics) to Sir Terence Conran (a 20th-century interior designer).

questions.question_text: People on the electoral register with ages between 18 and 70 can be asked to serve on a jury.
questions.explanation: True. As well as getting the right to vote, people on the electoral register are randomly selected to serve on a jury. Anyone who is on the electoral register and is aged 18 to 70 can be asked to do this.

questions.question_text: Which Saxon king of England was killed at the Battle of Hastings in 1066?
questions.explanation: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeatedHarold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle.

questions.question_text: During the ‘swinging sixties’ Britain experienced a growth in:

questions.question_text: As a permanent resident or citizen of the UK you should:

answers.text: Look after yourself and your family
Look after the area in which you live and the environment

questions.explanation: If you wish to be a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you should: respect and obey the law, respect the rights of others, including their right to their own opinions, treat others with fairness, look after yourself and your family and look after the area in which you live and the environment.

questions.question_text: When did the BBC start the world’s first regular television service?

questions.question_text: The evacuation of British and French soldiers from France in a huge naval operation during WWII gave rise to which phrase:
questions.explanation: During WWII as France fell, the British decided to evacuate British and French soldiers from France in a huge naval operation. Many civilian volunteers in small pleasure and fishing boats from Britain helped the Navy to rescue more than 300,000 men from the beaches around Dunkirk. The evacuation gave rise to the phrase‘the Dunkirk spirit’.

questions.question_text: Which programme helps 16 and 17 year-olds develop their skills and are part in community projects?

questions.question_text: Why is it important to recycle (select two answers)?

answers.text: Using recycled materials to make new products uses less energy than using raw materials
It is a criminal offence and you could be arrested if you do not do it
To reduce the expenses of the local council
Less rubbish is created, so the amount being put into landfill is reduced

questions.explanation: It is important to recycle as much of your waste as you can. Using recycled materials to make new productsuses less energy and means that we do not need to extract more raw materials from the earth. It also means that less rubbish is created, so the amount being put into landfill is reduced.

questions.explanation: As well as getting the right to vote,people on the electoral register are randomly selectedto serve on a jury. Anyone who is on the electoral register and is aged 18 to 70 can be asked to do this.

questions.question_text: What is a bank holiday?

A public holiday when banks and many other businesses are closed for the day

Solicitors’ charges are usually based on the nature of a case and its importance

questions.question_text: Which of the following territories is a Crown dependency but is NOT part of the UK?

That your dog does not bark

questions.question_text: When did Ireland become a republic?

questions.question_text: Who led the first invasion of Britain?

In AD 43 the Emperor Claudius led the Roman army in a new invasion. This time, there was resistance from some of the British tribes but the Romans were successful in occupying almost all of Britain.

questions.question_text: What is Good Friday?

The day when Jesus Christ was born

questions.question_text: During which period did the Beatles become popular and social laws were liberalised?
questions.explanation: The decade of the1960swas a period of significant social change. It was known as the ‘swinging sixties’. There was growth in British fashion, cinema and popular music. Two well-known pop music groups at the time were The Beatles and The Rolling Stones. It was also a time when social laws were liberalised, for example in relation to divorce and to abortion in England, Wales and Scotland. The position of women in the workplace also improved.

questions.question_text: The Man Booker Prize is awarded in which of the following categories?
questions.explanation: The Man Booker Prize for Fiction is awarded annually forthe best fiction novel (literature)written by an author from the Commonwealth, Ireland or Zimbabwe. It has been awarded since 1968. Past winners include Ian McEwan, Hilary Mantel and Julian Barnes.

questions.question_text: What sort of election takes place when a member of the Parliament (MP) dies or resigns?
questions.explanation: If an MP dies or resigns, there will be a fresh election, called aby-election, in his or her constituency.

questions.question_text: What is the Turner Prize?
questions.explanation: The Turner Prize was established in 1984 and celebratescontemporary art. The Turner Prize is recognised as one of the most prestigious visual art awards in Europe.

questions.question_text: Which flower is associated with Northern Ireland?
questions.explanation: The flower associated with Northern Ireland isthe shamrock.

questions.question_text: The last battle between Britain and France was the battle of Waterloo.
questions.explanation: This statement istrue.

questions.question_text: £100 is the highest value note in circulation in the UK.
questions.explanation: This statement isfalse.

questions.question_text: Where is the Lake District National Park located?
questions.explanation: Lake District is inEngland.

questions.question_text: Which two responsibilities will you have as a British citizen?

answers.text: To volunteer in a community project at least once a year
To look after yourself and your family
To respect the rights of others, including their right to their own opinions

questions.explanation: If you wish to be a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you should: respect and obey the law,look after yourself and your family,respect the rights of others, including their right to their own opinions,treat others with fairness and look after the area in which you live and the environment.

questions.question_text: Who was born in Stratford-upon-Avon?
questions.explanation: William Shakespearewas born in Stratford-upon-Avon, England.

questions.question_text: Why is 1928 an important year in women’s voting history?

answers.text: Women were given the right to vote at the age of 18, the same as men.
Women were given the right to vote at the age of 25.
Women were given the right to vote at the age of 30.
Women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, the same as men.

questions.explanation: Women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, the same as men.

questions.question_text: What does Hogmanay refer to?
questions.explanation: In Scotland,the 31st of December (New Year’s Eve)is called Hogmanay.

questions.question_text: What is the capital city of Northern Ireland?
questions.explanation: The capital city of Northern Ireland isBelfast.

questions.question_text: Which of the following wars took place between 1899 and 1902 in South Africa?
questions.explanation: The Boer War.

questions.question_text: Northern Ireland uses a system called ‘individual registration’ and all those entitled to vote must complete their own registration form.
questions.explanation: This statement isTrue.

questions.question_text: Which two of the following policies are not controlled by the devolved administrations?
questions.explanation: Policy and laws governing defence, foreign affairs, immigration, taxation and social security all remain under central UK government control.However, many other public services, such as education, are controlled by the devolved administrations.

questions.question_text: How old do citizens of the UK, the Irish Republic or the Commonwealth have to be to stand for public office?
questions.explanation: Most citizens of the UK, the Irish republic or the Commonwealth aged18 or overcan stand for public office. There are some exceptions, including: members of the armed forces, civil servants and people found guilty of certain criminal offences.

questions.question_text: How did the Government promote policies of free trade during the Victorian Age?

answers.text: Abolishing a number of taxes on imported goods
Abolishing the exportation of local produce
Preventing the importation of cheap raw materials
Preventing the importation of cheap grain

questions.explanation: During Victorian times, the government began to promote policies of free trade,abolishing a number of taxes on imported goods. One example of this was the repealing of the Corn Laws in 1846. These had prevented the import of cheap grain. The reforms helped the development of the British industry, because raw materials could now be imported cheaply.

questions.question_text: Who was Admiral Nelson?

answers.text: One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans
A British officer in charge of the British army at the Battle of Waterloo
A British general who established the authority of the English Parliament
A British officer in charge of the British fleet at the Battle of Trafalgar against the Spanish fleet

questions.explanation: Admiral Nelson wasin charge of the British fleet at the Battle of Trafalgar against the Spanish fleetand was killed in the battle.

questions.question_text: During the Middle Ages, who were the serfs?

answers.text: Peasants who had a small area of their lord’s agricultural land
Soldiers who fought at the Battle of Trafalgar
Noblemen who formed part of the king’s council of advisers
A group of skilled people from Holland who came to England during the Middle Ages

questions.explanation: Serfs werepeasants who had a small area of their lord’s land where they could grow food.

questions.question_text: Which invention lead to the rapid development of the industry in Britain during the 18th and 19th centuries?
questions.explanation: The Industrial Revolution was the rapid development of industry in Britain in the 18th and 19th centuries. Britain was the first country to industrialise on a large scale. It happened because of the development of machinery and the use ofsteam power.

questions.question_text: MPs can only be contacted by post.
questions.explanation: False. You can contact MPs byletter or telephoneat their constituency office, or at their office in the House of Commons. In addition, many MPs, Assembly members, MSPs and MEPs hold regular local ‘surgeries’, where constituents can go in person to talk about issues that are of concern to them.

questions.question_text: What movement challenged the authority of the Pope?
questions.explanation: The Reformationwas a movement against the authority of the Pope and the ideas and practices of the Roman Catholic Church.

questions.question_text: What English King introduced the Domesday Book?

answers.text: Harold, the Saxon king of England

questions.explanation: William the Conquerorsent people all over England to draw up lists of all the towns and villages. The people who lived there, who owned the land and what animals they owned were also listed. This was called the Domesday Book.

questions.question_text: What did ’the Butler Act’ introduce in 1944?

answers.text: Free primary education in England, Wales and Scotland
Free university fees in England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland
Free primary and secondary education in England, Wales and Scotland
Free secondary education in England and Wales

questions.explanation: Richard Austen Butler became a Conservative MP in 1923 and held several positions before becoming responsible for education in 1941. In this role, he oversaw the introduction of the Education Act 1944 (often called ‘The Butler Act’), which introducedfree secondary education in England and Wales.

questions.question_text: What is the small claims procedure?

answers.text: An informal way of helping people to settle minor disputes without spending a lot of time and money using a lawyer
A procedure that helps people to make small home insurance claims in certain circumstances

questions.explanation: The small claims procedure isan informal way of helping people to settle minor disputes without spending a lot of time and money using a lawyer.

questions.question_text: What building was constructed in Hyde Park to hold the Great Exhibition of 1851?
questions.explanation: In 1851, the Great Exhibition opened in Hyde Park inthe Crystal Palace, a huge building made of steel and glass. Exhibits ranged from huge machines to handmade goods.

questions.question_text: Who was Florence Nightingale?
questions.explanation: Florence Nightingale wasa nurse. She is often regarded asthe founder of modern nursing.

questions.question_text: When is St George’s day?
questions.explanation: St George’s day, patron of England is celebrated on the23rd of April.

questions.question_text: Which is the largest National Park in England?

answers.text: Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park

questions.explanation: The Lake Districtis England’s largest national park.

questions.question_text: Boudicca, was a tribal leader who fought against which foreign invaders?
questions.explanation: One of the tribal leaders who fought againstthe Romanswas Boudicca, the queen of the Iceni.

questions.question_text: Which of the following poems is about a group of people going on a pilgrimage?
questions.explanation: Geoffrey Chaucer wrote a series of poems in English about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage. The people decided to tell each other stories on the journey, and the poems describe the travellers and some of the stories they told. This collection of poems is calledThe Canterbury Tales.

questions.question_text: How are public holidays called?
questions.explanation: There are public holidays each year calledbank holidays, when banks and many other businesses are closed for the day.

questions.question_text: How did Charles II manage to escape to Europe after his defeat in the Civil War?
questions.explanation: Charles II escaped from Worcester, famouslyhiding in an oak treeon one occasion, and eventually fled to Europe.

questions.question_text: Who defeated the Vikings?
questions.explanation: The Anglo-Saxon kingdoms in England united underKing Alfred the Great, who defeated the Vikings.

questions.question_text: Who was William Caxton?

answers.text: A poet who wrote about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage
The first person in England to print books using a printing press
The first person to sail singlehanded around the world

questions.explanation: William Caxton wasthe first person in England to print books using a printing press.

questions.question_text: Where do Beefeaters serve as tour guides?
questions.explanation: Beefeaters serve as tour guides atthe Tower of London.

questions.question_text: During the rebellion of the clans in Scotland, Bonnie Prince Charlie was supported by clansmen from which Scottish region?
questions.explanation: Charles Edward Stuart (Bonnie Prince Charlie) was supported by clansmen fromthe Scottish Highlands.

questions.question_text: What religion did Elizabeth I follow?
questions.explanation: Elizabeth the I was aprotestant.

questions.question_text: Who became famous for his tramp character in silent movies?
questions.explanation: Charlie Chaplinbecame famous in silent movies for his tramp character.

questions.question_text: Which armed force was used in the Battle of Britain?
questions.explanation: The correct answer isthe Royal Air Force.

questions.question_text: In the UK, you have to be 21 years old to be able to vote in a general election.
questions.explanation: False. The present voting age of18was set in 1969 and (with a few exceptions) all UK-born and naturalised adult citizens have the right to vote.

questions.question_text: Which of the following poets was inspired by nature?
questions.explanation: British poets, includingWilliam Wordsworth, were inspired by nature.

questions.question_text: Against which country did Britain fight at the Battle of Waterloo?
questions.explanation: In 1815, theFrenchWars ended with the defeat of the Emperor Napoleon by the Duke of Wellington at the Battle of Waterloo.

questions.question_text: Who was William Wilberforce?
questions.explanation: William Wilberforce, an evangelical Christian and a member of Parliament, also played an important part in changing the law. Along with other abolitionists (people who supported the abolition of slavery), he succeeded in turning public opinion against the slave trade.

questions.question_text: Who is the spiritual leader of the Church of England?
questions.explanation: The spiritual leader of the Church of England isthe Archbishop of Canterbury.

questions.question_text: James I was King of which country before becoming King of England?
questions.explanation: When Elizabeth I died, her cousinJames VI of Scotland became King James I of England, Wales and Irelandand Scotland remained a separate country.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements is correct?

answers.text: Most shops in the UK open seven days a week.
All shops in the UK close on Sundays and bank holidays.

questions.explanation: Most shops in the UK are open seven days a week, although trading hours on Sundays and public holidays are generally reduced.

questions.question_text: Which country sent a fleet of ships to England in 1588?
questions.explanation: Elizabeth became one of the most popular monarchs in English history, particularly after 1588, when the English defeated the Spanish Armada (a large fleet of ships), which had been sent bySpainto conquer England and restore Catholicism.

questions.question_text: Where is the National Horseracing Museum located?
questions.explanation: There is a National Horseracing Museum inNewmarket, Suffolk.

questions.question_text: Which of the following castles is located in Scotland?
questions.explanation: Crathes Castleis located in Scotland.

questions.question_text: Who was a famous Art Deco ceramic designer?
questions.explanation: Britain has produced many great designers, from Thomas Chippendale (who designed furniture in the 18th century) toClarice Cliff(who designed Art Deco ceramics) to Sir Terence Conran (a 20th-century interior designer).

questions.question_text: When is St Patrick’s day celebrated?
questions.explanation: St Patrick’s day, patron of Northern Ireland is celebrated on the17th of March.

questions.question_text: How are the members of the Northern Ireland Parliament elected?

answers.text: By a system of proportional representation
Using a system of ranked voting
Using the first past the post system

questions.explanation: The Northern Ireland Assembly has 90 elected members, known as MLAs (members of the Legislative Assembly). They are electedwith a form of proportional representation.

questions.question_text: Who was the first British Prime Minister?
questions.explanation: The most important minister in Parliament became known as the Prime Minister. The first man to be called this wasSir Robert Walpole, who was Prime Minister from 1721 to 1742.

questions.question_text: Which of the following actresses has not won an Oscar?
questions.explanation: British actors to have won Oscars include Colin Firth, Sir Antony Hopkins, Dame Judi Dench, Kate Winslet and Tilda Swinton.Emily Watson has not won an Oscar yet.

questions.question_text: During the Enlightenment, Adam Smith developed ideas about:
questions.explanation: During ’the Enlightenment’ Adam Smith developed ideas abouteconomicswhich are still referred to today.

questions.question_text: Who died at the Battle of Trafalgar?
questions.explanation: Admiral Nelsonwas in charge of the British fleet at Trafalgar and was killed in the battle.

questions.question_text: When is Hogmanay celebrated?
questions.explanation: In Scotland,the 31st of Decemberis called Hogmanay.

questions.question_text: Proceedings in Parliament are broadcast on television and published in official reports known as:
questions.explanation: Proceedings in Parliament are broadcast on television and published in official reports calledHansard.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a rugby competition?
questions.explanation: The most famous rugby union competition isthe Six Nations Championshipbetween England, Ireland, Scotland, Wales, France and Italy.

questions.question_text: Who appoints life peers in the House of Lords?
questions.explanation: Life peers are appointed bythe monarchon the advice of the Prime Minister.

questions.question_text: Who mapped the coast of Australia?
questions.explanation: Captain James Cookmapped the coast of Australia and a few colonies were established there.

questions.question_text: What was the first war to be extensively covered by the media?
questions.explanation: The Crimean Warwas the first war to be extensively covered by the media through news stories and photographs.

questions.question_text: Which of the following monuments is located in Wiltshire?
questions.explanation: Stonehengestands in what is now the English county of Wiltshire.

questions.question_text: Who was the first Archbishop of Canterbury?
questions.explanation: St Augustineled missionaries from Rome, who spread Christianity in the south. St Augustine became the first Archbishop of Canterbury.

questions.question_text: How old do you have to be to go into betting shops or gambling clubs?
questions.explanation: You have to be18to go into betting shops or gambling clubs.

questions.question_text: The system of government in the UK is a parliamentary democracy.
questions.explanation: This statement istrue.

questions.question_text: What is the traditional food of Northern Ireland?
questions.explanation: Ulster fryis the correct answer.

questions.question_text: Who was elected as British Prime Minister in 1945?
questions.explanation: In 1945 the British people elected a Labour government. The new Prime Minister wasClement Attlee.

questions.question_text: How many times has the UK hosted the Olympic games?
questions.explanation: The UK has hosted the Olympic games onthreeoccasions: 1908, 1948 and 2012.

questions.question_text: Why were canals built during the Industrial Revolution?

answers.text: To link the factories to towns and cities and to the ports
To make space for the large fleet of British ships
To increase the number of water mills in the UK
To increase the amount of water in towns and cities

questions.explanation: Canals were builtto link the factories to towns and cities and to the ports, particularly in the new industrial areas in the middle and north of England.

questions.question_text: Are civil servants appointed by the government?
questions.explanation: Civil servantsare accountable to ministers. They are chosen on merit and are politically neutral – theyare not political appointees.

questions.question_text: Which of the following countries helped Britain to develop the Concorde?
questions.explanation: Britain andFrancedeveloped the world’s only supersonic commercial airliner, Concorde.

questions.question_text: Which invention led to the development of Britain during the Industrial Revolution?
questions.explanation: The Industrial Revolution was the rapid development of industry in Britain in the 18th and 19th centuries. Britain was the first country to industrialise on a large scale. It happened because of the development of machinery and the use ofsteam power.

questions.question_text: Who was the tribal leader who fought against the Romans?
questions.explanation: One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans wasBoudicca.

questions.question_text: Which two languages were used across England during the Middle Ages?
questions.explanation: The Middle Ages saw the development of a national culture and identity. After the Norman Conquest, the king and his noblemen had spokenNorman Frenchand the peasants had continued to speakAnglo-Saxon.

questions.question_text: In 1776, which British colonies declared their independence because they demanded that there should be ‘no taxation without representation‘.
questions.explanation: In 1776, 13North Americancolonies declared their independence, stating that people had a right to establish their own governments.

questions.question_text: When was England ruled by a republic and not by a monarch?

answers.text: When Elizabeth I died without any successor
When the Carta Magna restricted the king’s power
When kind Harold died after the Battle of Hastings

questions.explanation: When Charles I was executed, England declared itself a republic, called the Commonwealth. It no longer had a monarch.

questions.question_text: Which film produced in the UK was one of the most commercially successful films of all time and one of the highest-grossing film franchises?
questions.explanation: Some of the most commercially successful films of all time, including the two highest-grossing film franchises (Harry Potterand James Bond), have been produced in the UK.

questions.question_text: When did the first farmers come to Britain?
questions.explanation: The first farmers arrived in Britain6,000 years ago.

questions.question_text: When did the First World War end?
questions.explanation: The First World War endedat 11.00 am on 11th November 1918with victory for Britain and its allies.

questions.question_text: Can court orders be obtained to protect a person from being forced into a marriage?
questions.explanation: True. Court orders can be obtained to protect a person from being forced into a marriage, or to protect a person in a forced marriage.

questions.question_text: What medal did Mary Peters win in the 1972 Olympics?

answers.text: She did not win any medals

questions.explanation: Born in Manchester, Mary Peters moved to Northern Ireland as a child. She was a talented athlete who wonan Olympic gold medalin the pentathlon in 1972.

questions.question_text: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland Youth Court cases are normally heard by (choose TWO answers)?
questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, if an accused person is aged 10 to 17, the case is normally heard in a Youth Court in front ofup to three specially trained magistrates or a District Judge.

questions.question_text: What was invented by Alan Turing in the 1930s?
questions.explanation: ATuring machineis a theoretical mathematical device invented by Alan Turing (1912-54), a British mathematician, in the 1930s.

questions.question_text: Which of the following tells us about how people lived in England just after the Norman Conquest?
questions.explanation: William sent people all over England to draw up lists of all the towns and villages. The people who lived there, who owned the land and what animals they owned were also listed. This was calledthe Domesday Book. It still exists today and gives a picture of society in England just after the Norman Conquest.

questions.question_text: Who led a team of scientists to ‘split the atom‘ for the first time?
questions.explanation: Scientists led byErnest Rutherford, working at Manchester and then Cambridge University, were the first to ‘split the atom‘ and took part in the Manhattan Project in the United States, which developed the atomic bomb.

questions.question_text: What song is sung by people in the UK and other countries when they are celebrating the New Year?
questions.explanation: The song Auld Lang Syne, which is sung by people in the UK and other countries when they are celebrating the New Year (or Hogmanay as it is called in Scotland).

questions.question_text: Who fought in the English Civil war of 1642?

answers.text: The House of York and the House of Lancaster
The House of Fraser and the House of Stuart

questions.explanation: The Civil war between the king and Parliament began in 1642. The country split into those who supported the king (the Cavaliers) and those who supported Parliament (the Roundheads).

questions.question_text: Which two of these forts were part of Hadrian‘s wall?
questions.explanation: Parts of Hadrian‘s Wall, include the forts ofHousesteads and Vindolanda.

questions.question_text: What was the religion of the Puritans?
questions.explanation: The Puritans were a group ofProtestantswho advocated strict and simple religious doctrine and worship.

questions.question_text: What is the name of Irish people who favoured complete independence from the UK in the 19th century?
questions.explanation: The Irish Nationalist movement had grown strongly through the 19th century. Some, such asthe Fenians, favoured complete independence.

questions.question_text: Which two British pop music groups were famous during the Swinging Sixties?
questions.explanation: The decade of the 1960s was a period of significant social change. It was known as the ‘swinging sixties’. There was growth in British fashion, cinema and popular music. Two well-known pop music groups at the time wereThe BeatlesandThe Rolling Stones.

questions.question_text: What is the minimum age required to drive a motorcycle?
questions.explanation: In the UK, you must be at least17years to drive a car or motorcycle and you must have a driving licence to drive on public roads.

questions.question_text: The members of the House of Lords, known as peers, are elected by the people.
questions.explanation: False. The members of the House of Lords, known as peers,are not elected by the people.

questions.question_text: When did the Emancipation Act abolish slavery throughout the British Empire?
questions.explanation: In1833the Emancipation Act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire.

questions.question_text: Who is responsible for crime, policing and immigration?
questions.explanation: The Home Secretaryis responsible for crime, policing and immigration.

questions.question_text: What kind of genre was the film Wallace and Gromit created by Nick Park?
questions.explanation: Nick Park won four Oscars for hisanimated films, including three for films featuring Wallace and Gromit.

questions.question_text: Anyone who is violent towards their partner – whether they are a man or a woman, married or living together – can be prosecuted.
questions.explanation: True. Anyone who is violent towards their partner – whether they are a man or a woman, married or living together – can be prosecuted.
